Uniform Player Contract

 Every Player signs a **Uniform Player Contract (UPC)**. The UPC contains required language in every Contract, and then has **Exhibits** that can be adjusted based upon the agreements of the parties. Below you will find an explanation of the Exhibits, while the rules concerning the substance of the Exhibits will be found in other areas of the Guide.

title: Limited Amendments to UPC
content:
The terms of the UPC cannot be amended other than as expressly permitted in the CBA.

The CBA and the UPC has 10 Exhibits that can be included in the Contract as agreed upon by the Team and Player.

title: Exhibit 1 ‚Äì Compensation
Exhibit 1A ‚Äì Minimum Salary Contract
content: Exhibit 1A will expressly state if the Contract is a Minimum Contract (i.e. for the applicable [Minimum Salary](https://cbaguide.com/contractanatomy/terms/contractlimitations/) with no bonuses of any kind, other than potentially a [Trade Bonus](https://cbaguide.com/contractanatomy/terms/paymentarrangements/#tradebonus) or [Exhibit 10 Bonus](https://cbaguide.com/contractanatomy/contracttypes/#exhibit10)).

title: Exhibit 1B ‚Äì Two-Way Contract
content: Exhibit 1B identifies if the Contract is a [Two-Way Contract](https://cbaguide.com/contractanatomy/contracttypes/#twoway).

title: Exhibit 2 ‚Äì Compensation Protection
content: Exhibit 2 identifies any [Compensation Protection](https://cbaguide.com/contractanatomy/terms/compensationprotection/) (i.e. guaranteed salary).

title: Exhibit 3 ‚Äì Prior Injury Exclusion
content: Exhibit 3 identifies if there is an injury excluded from any Compensation Protection, called a [Prior Injury Exclusion](https://cbaguide.com/contractanatomy/terms/compensationprotection/#priorinjury).

title: Exhibit 4 ‚Äì Trade Payments
content: Exhibit 4 identifies any Trade Payments, which is oftentimes called a [Trade Bonus](https://cbaguide.com/contractanatomy/terms/paymentarrangements/#tradebonus) or a Trade Kicker.

title: Exhibit 5 ‚Äì Other Activities
content:
Exhibit 5 overrides the standard prohibited activities provision in the UPC, allowing the Player to participate in expressly identified activities.

The most typical is the right to play in pickup basketball games (that term being loosely defined), which is called the **For the Love of the Game** clause.

title: Exhibit 6 ‚Äì Physical Exam
content:
1. Requires Player to pass a physical exam prior to the Contract taking effect.
2. The Player must report for a physical exam designated by the Team (no later than the 3rd business day after the Contract is executed).
3. The determination of whether the Player passes the physical exam is determined in the Team‚Äôs sole discretion in good faith.
4. Team must provide notice of failure 6 days after physical.

title: Exhibit 7 ‚Äì Conditioning Provision
content:
Exhibit 7 replaces the standard Paragraph 7(b) in the UPC with a paragraph more favorable for the Player:

1. UPC 7(b):  
   * Allows the Team to suspend a Player without pay if he is out of shape not as a result of basketball.
2. Exhibit 7:  
   * Suspensions can only be successive one-week periods;  
   * Team must provide notice for each successive week;  
   * After each week, Player can appeal to an independent physician.

title: Exhibit 8 ‚Äì Sign/Extend & Trade
content: Exhibit 8 identifies the Contract as a [Sign-and-Trade](https://cbaguide.com/transactions/trades/signandtrade/) or [Extend-and-Trade](https://cbaguide.com/transactions/trades/signandtrade/#extend), conditioned on the Contract being traded to a new Team within 48 hours of its execution.

title: Exhibit 9 ‚Äì Training Camp Contract
content: Exhibit 9 identifies the Contract as a [Training Camp Contract](https://cbaguide.com/contractanatomy/contracttypes/#exhibit9) with no need to pay Base Compensation to the Player unless still in effect at the start of the Regular Season.

title: Exhibit 10 ‚Äì Conversion Contract
content: Exhibit 10 identifies the Contract as an [Exhibit 10 Contract](https://cbaguide.com/contractanatomy/contracttypes/#exhibit10) with the ability to convert the [Standard Contract](https://cbaguide.com/contractanatomy/contracttypes/#standard) to a [Two-Way Contract](https://cbaguide.com/contractanatomy/contracttypes/#twoway) prior to the Start of the Regular Season.

title: Promotional Activity Amendment
content:
The Team and Player can also agree to delete the following paragraph from the UPC, or otherwise delete only the underlined portion:

‚Äú_The Player agrees that, during any year of this Contract, he will not make public appearances, participate in radio or television programs, permit his picture to be taken, write or sponsor newspaper or magazine articles, or sponsor commercial products without the written consent of the Team, which shall not be withheld except in the reasonable interests of the Team or the NBA. The foregoing shall be interpreted in accordance with the decision in Portland Trail Blazers v. Darnell Valentine and Jim Paxson, Decision 86-2 (August 13, 1986)._‚Äú

Contract Types

title: Introduction
Standard NBA Contract
content: Any NBA Contract signed is considered a **Standard Contract** unless it is a [Two-Way Contract](#twoway).

title: Ten-Day Contracts Generally
content:
The **Ten-Day Contract** is a limited Contract allowing a Team to sign a Player for 10 days or 3 games.

It is typically used to fill the backend of the roster, particularly due to injury or for cost-saving measures.

Ten-Day Contracts can only be signed starting on January 5th, and Teams are limited to the amount of Ten-Day Signings based upon other Players on their Active and Inactive Lists at the time.

title: Dates of Eligibility
content:
Ten-Day Contracts can be signed starting on January 5th of each Season.

Not eligible if the Contract would extend past the date of the Team‚Äôs last Regular Season game.

* Exception ‚Äì A hardship waiver allows a 10-day Contract to be signed prior to January 5th, and would allow the Contract to run until the last day of the Regular Season if needed.

**üèÄ** **Pacers Sign Two 10-Day Contracts per Hardship Rules**  
During the 2025-26 Season, the Pacers were permitted to sign Jeremiah Robinson-Earl and Cody Martin to 10-Day Contracts as their 19th and 20th Players on the Roster pursuant to the hardship exception.

title: Length
content: The _longer_ of (i) ten days or (ii) a period encompassing three games played by the Team.

title: Salary
content:
Apply the [Minimum Salary](https://cbaguide.com/contractanatomy/terms/contractlimitations/), prorated over the number of days of the Contract.

**üèÄ** **Veteran Payton Signs 10-Day with Pelicans**  
On April 2, 2025, Elfrid Payton signed a 10-Day Contract with the Pelicans. Payton had 8 Years of Service at the time of signing.  
  
Payton‚Äôs Minimum Salary for 8 YOS: $2,988,550  
Payton‚Äôs Per-Day Minimum Salary: $17,175.57 ($2,988,550 √∑ 174 = $17,175.57)  
Payton‚Äôs 10-Day Contract: $171,755.74 ($17,175.57 x 10 = $171,755.74)  
  
Payton‚Äôs Earnings from 10-Day Contract: **$171,756** 
  
**Keep in mind, his Minimum Salary is [subsizied](https://cbaguide.com/contractanatomy/terms/compensation/salary/#oneyear) to 2 YOS for Cap, Apron and Tax purposes:** 
  
**Salary for 2 YOS: $2,087,519** 
**Per-Day Subsidized Salary: $11,997.24 ($2,087,519 √∑ 174 = $11,997.24)** 
**Payton‚Äôs 10-Day Contract Subsidized: $119,972 ($11,997.24 x 10 = $119,972.36)** 
  
**Payton‚Äôs Salary for Team Salary, Apron and Tax: $119,972**

title: Termination
content:
Only written notice is required to terminate the Contract, with no [Waiver](https://cbaguide.com/transactions/waivers/) procedure.

The Team cannot resign the Player until the term of the original Contract expires.

title: Amendment to Rest-of-Season Contract
content: While the Ten-Day Contract is in effect, the Team and Player can sign a [Rest-of-Season Contract](#rest) that goes into effect once the Ten-Day Contract expires.

title: Number of Ten-Day Signings
content:
One Team cannot sign a single Player to more than two Ten-Day Contracts.

A Team is limited to the number of Ten-Day Contracts at one time, dependent on the number of Players it has on its [Active/Inactive List](https://cbaguide.com/eligibility/rosters/), including the Ten-Day Contracts:

| Players on Active/Inactive List | Ten-Day Contracts Permitted |
| ------------------------------- | --------------------------- |
| 12                              | 0                           |
| 13                              | 1                           |
| 14                              | 2                           |
| 15                              | 3                           |

title: Rest-of-Season Contract
content:
Once the Regular Season begins, Players signing new Standard Contracts that are not Ten-Day Contracts are signing **Rest-of-Season Contracts**.

The Rest-of-Season refers to the remainder of the current Season, but the Contract can include future Seasons as well.

Oftentimes, the Player will be signed using the [Minimum Exception](https://cbaguide.com/thresholds/salarycap/#minimum). However, Teams that still have portions of their [Mid-Level Exceptions](https://cbaguide.com/thresholds/salarycap/#ntmle) or Cap Space available may entice Players to sign with them for more than their [Minimum Salary](https://cbaguide.com/contractanatomy/terms/contractlimitations/).

**üèÄ** **Castleton Signs Rest-of-Season Over the Minimum**  
In 2024-25, the Raptors signed Colin Castleton to a 2-Year Rest-of-Season Contract at the very end of the Regular Season on April 13th. Toronto used a portion of their remaining NTMLE to sign Castleton to a $100,000 salary for the rest of the Season, which was more than his applicable Minimum Salary. This gave Castleton more Compensation while giving Toronto team control over Castleton for the 2025-26 Season.

Salary will be prorated based upon the number of days remaining in the Season.

**üèÄ** **Walker‚Äôs Rest-of-Season Contract Prorated**  
During the 2024-25 Season, Lonnie Walker signed a Rest-of-Season Contract with the 76ers that included a Team Option for the 2025-26 Season. His Minimum Salary was $2,613,120\. With 52 days remaining in the season, his prorated salary was $780,932.  
  
$2,613,120 (√∑) 174 = $15,017.93 per-day Salary.  
$15,017.93 x 52 = $780,932 pro-rated Salary.

Teams will optimize the Rest-of-Season Contracts later in the Regular Season to stay below a particular Cap/Tax/Apron threshold while satisfying minimum [Roster](https://cbaguide.com/eligibility/rosters/) requirements.

**üèÄ** **Knicks Delay Converting Hukporti Contract to Save Team Salary**  
Entering the 2024-25 Season, the Knicks were pressed against the Second Apron where they were [hard capped](https://cbaguide.com/thresholds/apron/#hardcap) after acquiring Karl-Anthony Towns. They had signed Second Round Pick Ariel Hukporti to a Two-Way Contract at the start of the Season while carrying the [minimum 12 Standard Contracts](https://cbaguide.com/eligibility/rosters/), which is only permitted for a limited time.  
  
The Knicks later converted his Contract to a Rest-of-Season Contract to help get to the necessary [14 Standard Contracts](https://cbaguide.com/eligibility/rosters/). Had he signed at the start of the Season his Salary would have been $1,157,153\. Waiting until November 4th, his salary was prorated to $1,064,049, saving them close to $100,000 in Team Salary.

title: Two-Ways Generally
content:
The Two-Way Contract allows a Player to play for both an NBA Team and its G League affiliate while not taking a Standard Contract [Roster Spot](https://cbaguide.com/eligibility/rosters/). 

The Team can convert the Two-Way Contract to a Standard NBA Contract.

The NBA Team has exclusive rights to the Player under a Two-Way Contract (unlike G League Contracts, which contain no exclusivity and any NBA Team can sign).

The Two-Way Contract is limited in the amount of games a Player can be on the [NBA Roster](https://cbaguide.com/eligibility/rosters/), and only Players with 4 [YOS](https://cbaguide.com/definitions/#yos) or less are eligible to sign Two-Way Contracts, subject to exception.

title: Two-Way Contract Terms
content:
### Conversion Option

Every Two-Way Contract contains a **Two-Way Conversion Option** allowing the Team to convert it from a Two-Way Contract to a Standard Contract.

Can be converted after July 1 and must be converted prior to the start of the Team‚Äôs last Regular Season game.

The following occurs upon conversion:

1. The term length will remain the same as the Two-Way Contract;
2. Player is paid his applicable [Minimum Salary](https://cbaguide.com/contractanatomy/terms/contractlimitations/);

### Negotiating a New Standard Contract

The Player and Team can negotiate a _new_ Standard Contract, but such Contract may not include an [Exhibit 10](#exhibit10).

If executed, the Two-Way Contract is null and void.

**üèÄ** **Mitchell Signs New Rest-of-Season Contract with OKC**  
In 2024-25, Oklahoma City signed Ajay Mitchell to a 1-year Two-Way Contract. The Team could have converted his Contract to a Standard Contract for the remainder of the Season. Instead, OKC and Mitchell agreed to a new 2-year Contract for more Salary than the Minimum. OKC used the [Room MLE](https://cbaguide.com/thresholds/salarycap/#room) to sign Mitchell for over the [Minimum Salary](https://cbaguide.com/contractanatomy/terms/contractlimitations/).

**üí°** **Note the difference between Conversion and a new Standard Contract.**A Team has the option to convert a Two-Way Contract to the Player‚Äôs Minimum Salary for the same term length as the Two-Way Contract. This conversion option does not have to be agreed upon with the Player. The Team and Player can also agree to a new Contract, where the Team and Player can agree to a term longer than the original Two-Way Contract, and for more money than the applicable [Minimum Salary](https://cbaguide.com/contractanatomy/terms/contractlimitations/), provided the team has [Room](https://cbaguide.com/definitions/#room) to do so.

### Salary

Players earn 50% of the [Minimum Salary](https://cbaguide.com/contractanatomy/terms/contractlimitations/) applicable to Minimum Salary for Players with 0 [Years of Service](https://cbaguide.com/definitions/#yos).

Salary will be prorated should the Player not be signed for the entire Regular Season.

### Length

The length cannot exceed 2 years and cannot include [Options or ETO‚Äôs](https://cbaguide.com/contractanatomy/terms/options/).

### Payment Arrangements

Cannot include Loans, Bonuses, Incentive Compensation, Deferred Compensation or alternative pay schedules.

### Compensation Protection

**Maximum Two-Way Protection Amount**

The Maximum Two-Way Protection Amount is $85,300, which increases each season in line with the Salary Cap.

* Exception ‚Äì If Two-Way Contract signed after first day of Regular Season, [Protection](https://cbaguide.com/contractanatomy/terms/compensationprotection/) is limited to 50% [Base Compensation](https://cbaguide.com/contractanatomy/terms/compensation/basecompensation/).

**Conditional Protection**

[Compensation Protection](https://cbaguide.com/contractanatomy/terms/compensationprotection/) can be conditional up to 50% of [Base Compensation](https://cbaguide.com/contractanatomy/terms/compensation/basecompensation/) based upon the Team not waiving the Player by a certain date on or after the start of the Regular Season.

title: Two-Way Limitations
content:
### Eligibility

**Dates of Eligibility**

Cannot be signed after March 4th.

**Player Eligibility**

Cannot sign a Player to a [Two-Way Contract](https://cbaguide.com/contractanatomy/contracttypes/#twoway) who has _or could have_ 4+ [YOS](https://cbaguide.com/definitions/#yos) at any point during the Contract:

* Exception ‚Äì Permitted if Player has 4 [YOS](https://cbaguide.com/definitions/#yos) and was credited with 1 or more YOS with which (i) he did not play in any game and (ii) was on a Team‚Äôs roster at all times from the first day of the Regular Season through the end of the last day of the Regular Season.

**Team Eligibility**

Cannot sign, convert or acquire a Two-Way Player if the Player was under a Two-Way Contract for _any part_ of more than 3 Salary Cap Years with the same NBA Team.

### Number of Two-Way Signings

Cannot have more than three Two-Way Contracts signed to the [Roster](https://cbaguide.com/eligibility/rosters/) at one Time.

Player cannot be on the [Active List](https://cbaguide.com/eligibility/rosters/) for more than 50 Games, which is prorated should he be signed after the start of the Regular Season.

A Team cannot have more than 90 **Under Fifteen Games** during the Regular Season.

* Calculating Under Fifteen Games: (i) The Team has fewer than 15 Players signed to Standard NBA Contracts and (ii) the number of Two-Way Players on the Active List for such game is the number counted toward Under-Fifteen Games (i.e. if there are 13 players signed to Standard Contracts and 2 Two-Way Players on the Active List for the game, then it counts as two Under-Fifteen Games).

title: Two-Ways and Team Salary
content: Two-Way Contracts do _not_ count toward [Team Salary](https://cbaguide.com/thresholds/teamsalary/).

title: Exhibit 10‚Äôs Generally
content:
An Exhibit 10 Contract is a Standard Contract that allows the Team to convert the Contract to a Two-Way Contract (essentially the reverse of a Two-Way Contract).

Exhibit 10‚Äôs also allow a Team to sign a Player to a non-guaranteed Contract, but include a bonus, called an **Exhibit 10 Bonus**, discussed in more detail below.

**üèÄ** **Gortman Signs Exhibit 10 with Dallas, Converts to Two-Way**  
Jazian Gortman signed an Exhibit 10 Contract with the Dallas Mavericks in the 2024 Offseason. Dallas converted his Exhibit 10 Contract to a Two-Way Contract prior to the Regular Season.

title: Conversion Option
Number of Exhibit 10‚Äôs
content: No Team may sign more than 6 Contracts containing an Exhibit 10 at one time.

title: Exhibit 10 Contract Terms
content:
### Required Terms

Must be for 1 Season and for [Minimum Salary](https://cbaguide.com/contractanatomy/terms/contractlimitations/).

Cannot provide for Bonuses other than an Exhibit 10 Bonus (below).

No [Compensation Protection](https://cbaguide.com/contractanatomy/terms/compensationprotection/) permitted other than the Exhibit 10 Conversion Protection Amount (below).

### Conversion Protection

An Exhibit 10 Contract can have [Compensation Protection](https://cbaguide.com/contractanatomy/terms/compensationprotection/) (for lack of skill/injury/illness) that triggers at the start of the Regular Season if it‚Äôs not terminated and/or if it‚Äôs converted to a Two-Way Contract.

The **Exhibit 10** **Conversion Protection Amount** can be between $5,000 and $85,300 (increases in line with the Salary Cap), but must match the Exhibit 10 Bonus amount, if an Exhibit 10 Bonus (discussed below) is contained in the Contract.

### Exhibit 10 Bonus

**Amount of Exhibit 10 Bonus**

Can be between $5,000 and $85,300 (increases in line with the Salary Cap).

An Exhibit 10 Bonus does _not_ count toward [Team Salary](https://cbaguide.com/thresholds/teamsalary/).

**How Exhibit 10 Bonus is Triggered**

An Exhibit 10 Bonus is triggered when the following elements are satisfied:

1. Waived prior to the Regular Season;
2. Player signs with G League Team prior to the deadline to designate affiliated players;
3. Assigned to the G League affiliate and timely reports;
4. Provides 60-days of consecutive service (injury does not stop clock).

### Trade of an Exhibit 10 Contract

If a G League Affiliate acquires an Exhibit 10 Contract via trade and the Contract contains Conversion Protection, but not an Exhibit 10 Bonus, then the Exhibit 10 is deemed to include an Exhibit 10 Bonus equal to the Conversion Protection Amount.

### Exhibit 9 and Exhibit 10

A Contract can include both Exhibits 9 and 10\. However, if a Contract is converted to a [Two-Way Contract](#twoway), then the [Exhibit 9](#exhibit9) is null and void.

**üèÄ** Olivier Sarr signed an Exhibit 10 Contract that included an Exhibit 9 and an Exhibit 10 Bonus of $85,300.

### Two-Way Conversion and Exhibit 10

If a [Two-Way Contract](#twoway) is converted into a Standard Contract, the Standard Contract cannot include an Exhibit 10.

title: G League Rights
content:
**G League Rights** **Generally**

The G League‚Äô operates on universal 1-year Contracts for all Players. In determining which Team has priority to sign the Player in the offseason, there is an order of priority for assiging the Players, based on the type of ‚ÄúRights‚Äù the Team may have to a Player.

Two of those are **Returning Rights** and **Affiliate Rights.**

1. Returning Rights ‚Äì Players who played the prior G League season with the G League Team; and
2. Affiliate Rights -Players who participated in Training Camp with the G League Team‚Äôs affiliated NBA Team.

Returning Rights have preference over Affiliate Rights.

**G League Rights and the Exhibit 10 Bonus**

The Exhibit 10 Bonus is awarded to an **Affiliate Player** when he is waived by the NBA Team, and then is assigned to the G League affiliate Team.

What happens if another Team has Returning Rights to the Affiliate Player and therefore signs him using its priority over the Team with the Affiliate Rights?

The Player will be ineligible for the Exhibit 10 Bonus because he does not play for the affiliate G League Team.

**Notice of Returning Rights**

The NBA Team, when signing him to his Exhibit 10 Contract, is required to provide notice that a different NBA G League Affiliate holds his Returning Rights . This allows the Player to understand the risk that he may not play for the affiliate G League Team if his Exhibit 10 Contract is waived.

**üèÄ** **A G League Hypothetical**  
In the 2025 offseason, the Houston Rockets sign Player A to an Exhibit 10 Contract with an $85,300 Exhibit 10 Bonus.  
  
Prior to the Regular Season, the Rockets waive Player A, with the intention to have him play with their G League Affiliate, the Rio Grande Valley Vipers, using their Affiliate Rights to sign him. This would earn Player A his $85,300 bonus should he play for 60 consecutive days.  
  
However, Player A played the 2024-25 G League Season with the Austin Spurs, who have his Returning Rights and a higher priority to sign him over the Vipers. The Spurs sign him in the G League, and Player A loses out on his $85,300 (but should have had notice in his Exhibit 10 Contract with the Rockets that the Spurs had his Returning Rights).

title: Exhibit 9‚Äôs Generally
content:
An Exhibit 9 Contract is a **Training Camp Contract** that allows a Team so sign a Player to its Roster without the need to pay any [Base Compensation](https://cbaguide.com/contractanatomy/terms/compensation/basecompensation/) unless the Player makes the Regular Season roster.

The Exhibit 9 Contract allows the Player to compete in Training Camp for a [Roster Spot](https://cbaguide.com/eligibility/rosters/) while the Team bears no risk should they want to cut the Player prior to the Regular Season.

**‚úçÔ∏è** **Contract Required to Attend Training Camp**  
Note that no Player may attend training camp unless he is a party to a Contract then in effect. Exhibit 9 Contracts allow Teams to bring Player to Training Camp under a Contract with limited risk.

title: Exhibit 9 Contract Terms
Exhibit 9 Eligibility
content:
### Player Eligibility

A Team cannot sign a Veteran Free Agent to a Summer Contract if he last played for the Team unless (i) it is for 1 Season and (ii) provides for no more than the applicable [Minimum Salary](https://cbaguide.com/contractanatomy/terms/contractlimitations/).

### Team Eligibility

Team has no fewer than 14 Players signed to Standard NBA Contracts (this does not include Two-Way Contracts or Non-Guaranteed, Training Camp Contracts) on the [Team‚Äôs Roster](https://cbaguide.com/eligibility/rosters/) in respect of the upcoming Season.

One Team cannot have more than six Non-Guaranteed Training Camp Contracts.

title: Ex. 9 and Team Salary
content:
An Exhibit 9 Contract will not be counted toward [Team Salary](https://cbaguide.com/thresholds/teamsalary/) until the start of the Regular Season (called a **Summer Contract**).

The Contract must be waived prior to the start of the Regular Season, or the Team must have [Room](https://cbaguide.com/definitions/#room) to retain the Player‚Äôs Salary (likely using the [Minimum Exception](https://cbaguide.com/thresholds/salarycap/#minimum)).

title: The Rookie Scale Contract
content:
The [Rookie Scale Contract](https://cbaguide.com/transactions/signings/draftpicks/) is the Contract signed by all First Round Picks. 

Compensation

**Compensation** is the all-encompassing term for all money earned by a Player throughout the entire Contract. Compensation is then split into different subcategories, which has rules and limitations defined by the CBA.

title: Compensation ‚Äì Definition
content: Any compensation that is or _could be_ earned or paid to a Player (including those whose contracts have been terminated).

title: Generally
Compensation Types and the CBA
content:
Determining the Compensation Type is important, as each has different sets of limitations and are applied to different rules throughout the CBA.

**üèÄ** For example, Incentive Compensation can‚Äôt exceed 20% of Regular Salary. While Signing Bonuses can‚Äôt exceed 15% of Compensation, excluding Incentive Compensation.

title: Compensation Types ‚Äì General Definitions
content:
| Compensation Type      | Definition                                                                                                                                                       |
| ---------------------- | ---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- |
| Base Compensation      | Base Compensation is Compensation other than any bonuses of any kind.                                                                                            |
| Regular Salary         | Regular Salary is Compensation earned by the Player for a year less Signing Bonuses and Incentive Compensation.                                                  |
| Salary                 | Salary is all Compensation earned by the Player for a year other than Unlikely Bonuses and subject to certain adjustments.                                       |
| Incentive Compensation | Incentive Compensation encompasses three types of incentives: Performance Bonuses (Likely or Unlikely); Physical/Academic Achievements; Promotional Appearances. |
| Signing Bonus          | Signing Bonuses encompass three types of bonuses: Amounts earned upon the signing of the Contract; Trade Bonuses; Payments in excess of the EIPPA.               |

**‚úçÔ∏è** Some Compensation Types, or portions thereof, are contained within others. For example, Salary includes all Compensation except Unlikely Bonuses, which is one type of Incentive Compensation. While Regular Salary excludes all Incentive Compensation and Signing Bonuses.

Salary

**Salary** is the Compensation a Player earns for the Year, subject to certain adjustments if applicable. A Player‚Äôs Salary is what counts toward Team Salary in determining if the Team exceeds the Salary Cap.

title: What‚Äôs Included in Player‚Äôs Salary
Deferred Compensation
content:
[Deferred](https://cbaguide.com/contractanatomy/terms/paymentarrangements/#deferred)[ Compensation](https://cbaguide.com/contractanatomy/terms/paymentarrangements/#deferred) is included in a Player‚Äôs Salary for the Salary Cap Year encompassing the Season in which it was _earned_, not in the year it was paid.

The Contract shall identify the specific Season in which any Deferred Compensation is earned to allow for proper allocation in such Season.

title: General Rule
content:
The **Over 38 Rule** is designed to frontload the Cap hit for a Team when an aging Player is signed to a multi-year Contract.

It‚Äôs meant to avoid a situation where a Player signs a multi-year deal, retires early, and gets paid not to play while the Team benefits from spreading the Cap Hit across more Seasons.

If you don‚Äôt want to work through the math behind the rule, you can use the [Over 38 Calculator](https://cbaguide.com/resources/over38calculator/).

title: Roadmap of the Rule
content:
The below subsections go into detail in applying the rule in the following steps:

Step 1 ‚Äì Is there an Over 38 Contract triggering the rule?

Step 2 ‚Äì Determine which years are Over 38 Years and Non-Over 38 Years.

Step 3 ‚Äì Reallocate Salary at the beginning of the Contract.

Step 4 ‚Äì Reattribute Salary throughout each Season of the Contract.

title: Determining When the Rule Applies
content:
### Is it an ‚ÄúOver 38 Contract‚Äù?

Generally, an **Over 38 Contrac**t is:

1. A Contract, [Extension](https://cbaguide.com/transactions/extensions/) or [Renegotiation](https://cbaguide.com/transactions/renegotiations/) that is for 4+ Seasons at the time of Signing; and
2. The Player is 38 as of October 1st for at least one of those Seasons.

**Age Caveat**

You‚Äôll notice that all ages are based on the Player‚Äôs age as of October 1st of each Season, irrespective of when the Player is signed. There is one caveat:

If (i) a Player‚Äôs birthday is during the [Moratorium Period](https://cbaguide.com/calendar/), and (ii) signs the Over 38 Contract within 5 days after the Moratorium ends, then his age _at the time of signing_ is deemed his age as of the prior June 30th (i.e. prior to his birthday).

**Contract Length Breakdown**

The length of the Contract is a key factor in determining if it‚Äôs an Over 38 Contract, but it is based upon the Player‚Äôs age and [Bird Rights](https://cbaguide.com/thresholds/salarycap/#bird) status.

Any Contract 

Non-Full Bird Free Agents Only 

| Age at Time of Signing (Season 1) | Season 2 | Season 3 | Season 4 | Season 5 | Season 6\* |
| --------------------------------- | -------- | -------- | -------- | -------- | ---------- |
| 34                                | 35       | 36       | 37       | 38       | 39         |
| 35                                | 36       | 37       | 38       | 39       | 40         |
| 36                                | 38       | 38       | 39       | 40       | 41         |
| 37                                | 38       | 39       | 40       | 41       | 42         |

 \* Note that no Free Agents can sign 6-Year Contracts (Extensions only).

### Are there ‚ÄúOver 38 Years‚Äù?

Determining what Salaries to take and reallocate depends on whether the Player signed as a [Full Bird Free Agent](https://cbaguide.com/thresholds/salarycap/#bird) with his prior team or not.

**If not a Full Bird Free Agent**

If the Player is _not_ a Full Bird Free Agent, then you take all the Salaries starting from the _later_ of (i) the 4th Salary Cap Year of the Over 38 Contract or (ii) the first Year the Player is 38 as of October 1st.

These are the **Over 38 Years** and any years prior the **Non-Over 38 Years**.

**Full Bird Free Agents**

If a (i) [Full Bird Free Agent](https://cbaguide.com/thresholds/salarycap/#bird) signs with his Prior Team (ii) will be 35 or 36 at the time of signing and (iii) is not signed via [Sign-and-Trade,](https://cbaguide.com/transactions/trades/signandtrade/) then the following rules apply (note that if the age requirement is not reached, then apply the rule for Non Full Bird Free Agents above).

1. 4-Year Contract ‚Äì If it is a 4-year contract, then do _not_ reallocate any Salaries.
2. 5-Year Contract ‚Äì If it is a 5-year contract, then only reallocate the Salary from the 5th Year.

title: Reallocating Salary
content:
### Reallocation At the Time of Signing

If there‚Äôs an Over 38 Contract with at least one Over 38 Year, then reallocate the Salary from the Over 38 Years across the Non-Over 38 Years at the time of signing.

To do so, you take the total Salary from the Over 38 Years, and redistribute it in proportion to the percentage of Salary of the Non-Over 38 Years.

| Age   | Year         | Original Salary | Over 38 Year? | Percentage | Cap Hit     |
| ----- | ------------ | --------------- | ------------- | ---------- | ----------- |
| 36    | Year 1       | $45,000,000     | No            | 30.86%     | $80,555,556 |
| 37    | Year 2       | $48,600,000     | No            | 33.33%     | $87,000,000 |
| 38    | Year 3       | $52,200,000     | No            | 35.80%     | $93,444,444 |
| 39    | Year 4       | $55,800,000     | Yes           | ‚Äì          | ‚Äì           |
| 40    | Year 5       | $59,400,000     | Yes           | ‚Äì          | ‚Äì           |
| Total | $261,000,000 | $261,000,000    |               |            |             |

**üèÄ** In the above graphic, this non-Full Bird Free Agent signed a 5-year $261,000,000 Contract starting at the age of 36\.   
You see that 2 years are Over 38 Years, totaling $115,200,000 in Salary. This Salary is then Reallocated based on the Percentage of the Non-Over 38 Years. As you can see, this Player would have a significant Cap Hit based upon this rule, making the signing a non-starter.

### ‚ÄúReattribution‚Äù through the Life of the Contract

**When Does Reattribution Occur? ‚Äì The Timing**

The Reallocation above is not a fixed amount for the life of the Contract.

The remaining Salary will continue to be **Reattributed** if the Contract remains active throughout the life of the Contract. 

However, Reattribution does not automatically occur each Season. Instead, you apply the following rule: Reattribution occurs on a July 1st if (i) the Over 38 Contract remains active and (ii) an Over 38 Year is within 2 years of such July 1st.

**How Does Reattribution Occur? ‚Äì The Math**

If on July 1st, Reattribution is to occur, then the remaining Salary is aggregated _in equal shares_ to each of the _three_ or fewer Salary Cap Years. 

**‚úçÔ∏è** Notice that now the Salaries are not aggregated in proportion anymore, but are spread equally over the current Salary Cap Year as well as the following 2 Seasons (or 1 Season if there aren‚Äôt 2 Seasons remaining).

| Yearly Reattribution Cap Hit |              |                 |              |              |             |             |             |
| ---------------------------- | ------------ | --------------- | ------------ | ------------ | ----------- | ----------- | ----------- |
| Age                          | Year         | Original Salary | Year 1       | Year 2       | Year 3      | Year 4      | Year 5      |
| 36                           | Year 1       | $45,000,000     | $80,555,556  | ‚Äì            | ‚Äì           | ‚Äì           | ‚Äì           |
| 37                           | Year 2       | $48,600,000     | $87,000,000  | $60,148,148  | ‚Äì           | ‚Äì           | ‚Äì           |
| 38                           | Year 3       | $52,200,000     | $93,444,444  | $60,148,148  | $40,098,765 | ‚Äì           | ‚Äì           |
| 39                           | Year 4       | $55,800,000     | ‚Äì            | $60,148,148  | $40,098,765 | $40,098,765 | ‚Äì           |
| 40                           | Year 5       | $59,400,000     | ‚Äì            | ‚Äì            | $40,098,765 | $40,098,765 | $40,098,765 |
| Total                        | $261,000,000 | $261,000,000    | $180,444,444 | $120,296,296 | $80,197,531 | $40,098,765 |             |

**üèÄ** Using the same Contract from the Reallocation above, this graphic shows a year-by-year Reattribution of the Cap Hit. What you‚Äôll notice is that when you add the total Cap Hit hit for the year with the Cap Hit of the prior years, you will always equal the same amount of Salary from the original contract. In other words, for ‚ÄúCap Hit ‚Äì Year 4‚Äù the total Cap Hit is $80,197,531\. If you add the Cap Hits for the years that have occured in the prior years: $40,098,765, $60,148,148 and $80,555,556 you will get the same total of the Original Salary: $261,000,000 (subject to some rounding measures). This shows that the purpose of the rule is to always have the Team take the same Cap Hit over the life of the Contract, but absorb the majority of the Cap Hit in the front-end of the Contract under the assumption the Player will retire.
