2. [The Draft](https://cbaguide.com/eligibility/draftrules/) ‚Äì Discusses what happens when a Player is drafted (or is undrafted), how his Draft Rights are attached, and how the Team retains his Draft Rights until he signs a Contract.
3. Draft Pick Signings ‚Äì This page discusses what types of Contracts a Draft Pick (or Undrafted Player) signs based on where they were drafted (or undrafted).

title: Rookie Scale Contracts
content: If a Player is a First Round Pick, then the Player must sign a **Rookie Scale Contract**.

title: Term Length
content:
Every Rookie Scale Contract is a 4-Year Contract with Years 1 and 2 guaranteed and two Team Options for Years 3 and 4 called **Rookie Scale Team Options**.

The Rookie Scale Team Option has to be exercised by October 31st the Season _prior_ to the applicable Year.

If both Rookie Scale Team Options are exercised, the Player is an [RFA](https://cbaguide.com/transactions/signings/rfa/) entering the offseason of his 5th Season (unless he signs a [Rookie Scale Extension](https://cbaguide.com/transactions/extensions/) prior to his 4th Regular Season). 

If either Option is not exercised, he becomes a UFA. His Prior Team can still sign him over the Salary Cap. His starting Salary is limited to the Rookie Scale Team Option that was declined.

title: Salary
content:
### The ‚ÄúRookie Scale Amount‚Äù

The Player‚Äôs [Salary](https://cbaguide.com/contractanatomy/terms/compensation/salary/) must be within a fixed range based upon where the Player was selected in the [Draft](https://cbaguide.com/eligibility/draftrules/) (hence the term ‚ÄúRookie Scale‚Äù). This is called the Player‚Äôs applicable **Rookie Scale Amount**.

You can find the [Rookie Scale Salaries here](https://cbaguide.com/resources/rookiescale/).

Signing a Rookie Scale Contract is a [Salary Cap Exception](https://cbaguide.com/thresholds/salarycap/), allowing Teams to sign their First Round Picks over the Salary Cap.

The Player is to earn a minimum of 80% [Base Compensation](https://cbaguide.com/contractanatomy/terms/compensation/basecompensation/) of the Rookie Scale Amount, and can negotiate [Salary](https://cbaguide.com/contractanatomy/terms/compensation/salary/) and [Unlikely Bonuses](https://cbaguide.com/contractanatomy/terms/compensation/incentivecompensation/#performance) up to 120%.

It is common practice for Teams to pay the Player the 120% unless there is a specific reason for doing otherwise.

**üèÄ** **Pacome Dadiet Signs for Less than 120% with Knicks**  
In 2024, the Knicks signed Dadiet to his Rookie Scale Contract for only 80% Base Compensation in his first season. The reasoning came clear later that offseason when the Team traded for Karl Anthony-Towns and needed every dollar they could save to stay under the First Apron. Lessening Dadiet‚Äôs Salary saved the Knicks over $900,000.

### The Rookie Scale

The Rookie Scale is a baseline amount set initially with the 2023-24 Season and increases in line with the [Salary Cap](https://cbaguide.com/thresholds/salarycap/) each Season.

The **Baseline Rookie Scale Amount** is found in Exhibit B-1 of the CBA.

You can find the [Rookie Scale Salaries here](https://cbaguide.com/resources/rookiescale/).

title: Events Changing Rookie Scale Amount
content:
### Forfeiture of Draft Picks

If a Team is required to forfeit its Draft Pick, then the Salary Scale is adjusted for the applicable Draft to remove the 15th pick‚Äôs Rookie Scale Amount. If multiple Draft Picks are forfeited, then the 16th pick is removed, followed by the 14th, continuing in that order.

### Prorating Salary if Signed During Season

If a Player does not sign his Rookie Scale Contract until January 10th, his Salary will be prorated beginning January 10th, and will be reduced on a prorated daily amount (Rookie Scale Salary √∑ Regular Season Days = Daily Amount to Reduce).

### Trade Bonus

Similar to [Maximum Salary](https://cbaguide.com/contractanatomy/terms/contractlimitations/), if a [Trade Bonus](https://cbaguide.com/transactions/trades/tradebonus/) is triggered by a Rookie Scale Contract causing the Salary/Unlikely Bonuses to exceed 120%, then it‚Äôs reduced down to 120%.

### Signing During Regular Season // Non-NBA Contract

If a Player has a Non-NBA Contract, he can sign his Rookie Scale Contract from February 1st through June 30th to be effective _beginning the following Season_.

The Player is to receive the Rookie Scale Amount for the Season when the Contract begins. The Contract will state the percentage of the Salary Cap the Draft Pick is to receive, rather than a fixed amount.

Note that a Player can sign his Rookie Scale Contract while still under a non-NBA Contract, provided it expires prior to the effective date of the Rookie Scale Contract.

### Later-Signed First Round Picks

The applicable Rookie Scale Amount is the season in which the Rookie Scale Contract takes effect, and not the Season the Player is Drafted.

However, if a First Round Pick does not sign a Contract in the first three Seasons following his Draft, then the Team with [Draft Rights](https://cbaguide.com/eligibility/draftrules/) can sign him to either of the following:

1. Rookie Scale Contract for the Season _signed_ ; or
2. [Base Compensation](https://cbaguide.com/contractanatomy/terms/compensation/basecompensation/) greater than 120% of the Rookie Scale Amount provided the Team has [Room](https://cbaguide.com/definitions/#room), and the Contract is for a minimum of 3 Seasons (excluding Options).

**üèÄ** **Bogdanovic Signs with Kings Using Cap Space**  
In 2014, the Suns drafted Bogdan Bogdanovic with the 27th pick. After acquiring his Draft Rights in 2016, the Kings signed Bogdanovic in 2017\. The Rookie Salary Amount for the 27th pick in 2017 was $1,186,300\. However, the Kings used Cap Space to sign Bogdanovic to a starting Base Salary of $9,412,280.

### Loss of Draft Rights

If a Team loses the Draft Rights to the First Round Pick, then the Player will become a **Rookie Free Agent** free to sign with any Team.

However, the Team with [Draft Rights](https://cbaguide.com/eligibility/draftrules/) is prohibited from signing the Player until after he signed a Player Contract with another Team.

title: Additional Terms
content:
### Payments Arrangements

The following rules apply regarding [Payment Arrangements](https://cbaguide.com/contractanatomy/terms/paymentarrangements/) and Rookie Scale Contracts:

1. Signing Bonus ‚Äì Not permitted (other than EIPPA);
2. Loan ‚Äì Not permitted;
3. Payment Schedule ‚Äì Can agree to a more favorable Payment Schedule.

### Compensation Protection

Must provide for [Compensation Protection](https://cbaguide.com/contractanatomy/terms/compensationprotection/) for lack of skill/injury/illness of 80% of the Rookie Scale Amount in Years 1 and 2.

The Team and Player can negotiate any other conditions and limitations on Compensation Protection so long as Years 1 and 2 are protected.

title: Changing Terms Year-to-Year
content: The terms and conditions shall be unchanged from Year 3 and Year 4 other than Payment Schedule, and Salary/Bonuses shall increase by the applicable percentage in the Rookie Salary Scale.

title: Second Round Picks
content:
Teams that draft a Player in the Second Round have the _option_ (not a requirement) to sign him over the Salary Cap using the [Second Round Pick Exception](https://cbaguide.com/thresholds/salarycap/#second).

However, the Team is not restrained to the Exception and its terms, and can sign a Second Round Pick using any method of signing a Player, similar to a UFA.

In practice, Second Round picks will typically be offered terms within the Second Round Pick Exception, the [Minimum Exception](https://cbaguide.com/thresholds/salarycap/#minimum), or a [Two-Way Contract](https://cbaguide.com/contractanatomy/contracttypes/#twoway). Two-Way Contracts are more common the later into the Second Round a Player is drafted

title: Undrafted Rookie
content:
If a Player was eligibile for the Draft and went undrafted, he becomes a **Rookie Free Agent**.

A Rookie Free Agent can sign with any Team immediately upon the conclusion of the Draft. Oftentimes, Players will ask not to be drafted toward the end of the Second Round so they become Rookie Free Agents and can freely sign with their desired Team.

There is no separate Exception to sign a Rookie Free Agent. The Team must use Cap Space or another available Exception to sign the Player, unless signing him to a Two-Way Contract.

**üèÄ** **Love Goes Undrafted, Signs with Blazers**  
In 2025, Caleb Love went undrafted in the Draft. At the start of the Salary Cap Year, as a Rookie Free Agent, he signed a Two-Way Contract with the Trail Blazers.

title: Trade Restrictions
content:
The  Draft _Rights_ to a Player can be included in a Trade immediately when the Player is drafted. However, a Player that was drafted cannot be included in a Trade for 30 days after signing his Contract.

This does not include undrafted Rookie Free Agents, who fall into the rules for signing as any other Free Agent signing, which is the later of three months or December 15th.

**üí°** **Signing Draft Pick to Create Outgoing Trade Salary**  
When executing a Trade, the exchanging of Draft Rights count at $0 both as Incoming and Outgoing Trade Salary. If a the Sending Team needs more Outgoing Trade Salary to execute a Trade (and the Receiving Team can absorb the Incoming Trade Salary), then signing the Draft Pick before the Trade can create this additional Trade Salary. However, if the Teams were trying to execute the Trade during the Draft, the 30-day trade restriction will force the Trade into the next Salary Cap Year, which may affect the other Players‚Äô Trade Salaries.

Extensions

 Extensions have different rules based on the two different types of Extensions available to Players under Contract: **Rookie Scale Extensions** and **Veteran Extensions**. Rookie Scale Extensions are Extensions off of a Rookie Scale Contract. Any other Contract that is extended falls under Veteran Extension rules.  
  
Both the time when an Extension can be signed and the allowable terms of the Extension depend on whether it is a Rookie Scale Extension or Veteran Extension.

title: Player Eligibility
content:
Rookie Scale Extensions are only available to (i) Players currently playing under a Rookie Scale Contract and (ii) both Team Options have been exercised.

**‚úçÔ∏è** **Rookie Scale Extension Limited to First Round Picks**  
The Rookie Scale Extension rules are limited to Extensions off of Rookie Scale Contracts, and therefore are limited to First Round Picks.  
  
Any Second Round Picks or Unsigned Rookie Free Agents coming off their rookie Contracts will apply Veteran Extension rules below.

title: When Extension Can be Signed
content:
A Rookie Scale Extension can only be signed during the Second Option Year of the [Rookie Scale Contract](https://cbaguide.com/transactions/signings/draftpicks/), from 12:01 P.M. ET on the last day of the [Moratorium Period](https://cbaguide.com/calendar/) until 6:00 P.M. ET on the day prior to the start of the Regular Season.

**üèÄ** **2022 Drafted Players Eligible for Rookie Scale Extensions in 2025**  
In 2025, Players drafted in 2022 were eligible for Rookie Scale Extensions. For example, Chet Holmgren signed a 5-year, $239 million Rookie Scale Extension with the Thunder. Next offseason, First Round Picks drafted in 2023 will be eligible for Rookie Scale Extensions. 

Players that do not sign a Rookie Scale Extension by the start of the Regular Season will become [Restricted Free Agents](https://cbaguide.com/transactions/signings/rfa/) in the offseason. 

**üèÄ** **Mathurin and Ivey to Become RFA‚Äôs**  
Because Bennedict Mathurin and Jaden Ivey didn‚Äôt sign Rookie Scale Extensions prior to the start of the 2025-26 Regular Season, they are examples of Players that will become Restricted Free Agents in the 2026 offseason.

title: Salary
content:
### Maximum Amount Permitted

The Salary can be any amount up to his [Maximum Salary,](https://cbaguide.com/contractanatomy/terms/contractlimitations/) which is 25% of the Salary Cap, unless he satisfies the Higher Maximum Criteria. If he hits the [Higher Maximum Criteria](https://cbaguide.com/contractanatomy/terms/contractlimitations/#criteria), he can be offered up to 30% of the [Salary Cap](https://cbaguide.com/thresholds/salarycap/).

### Conditional Amount for Higher Max Criteria

If the Player hasn‚Äôt hit the [Higher Max Criteria](https://cbaguide.com/contractanatomy/terms/contractlimitations/#criteria) at the time of signing his Rookie Scale Extension, the increase can be conditional on him achieving the Higher Max Criteria in Year 4 of his Contract.

The Conditional Language can jump from 25% to 30% simply for achieving Higher Max Criteria or have levels based upon what is achieved.

**üèÄ** **Conditional Language Example**  
Starting Salary can be 25%, that will raise to 27.5% for Second Team All-NBA and 30% for First Team All-NBA, MVP or DPOY.

**üèÄ** **Timing of Achieving Higher Max Criteria is Crucial**  
**Ja Morant**  
Morant made All-NBA in Year 3, but didn‚Äôt achieve it for his Year 4 so he didn‚Äôt achieve the Higher Max Criteria and his starting Salary was set at 25%. **Trae Young**  
Young hadn‚Äôt earned All-NBA in his first 3 Seasons, but he earned All-NBA in Year 4, jumping his starting Salary from 25% to 30%. **Luka Doncic**  
Doncic achieved All-NBA in Year 2 and Year 3\. Therefore, he already reached the Higher Max Criteria when he signed his Rookie Scale Extension and was given 30% starting Salary with no conditions needed.

title: Length
content:
### Maximum

A Rookie Scale Extension can cover up to six Seasons from the date the Extension is signed (i.e. including the current Season and any [Option Year](https://cbaguide.com/contractanatomy/terms/options/)).

### Minimum

If a Rookie Scale Extension provides for Salary over 25% then the Rookie Scale Extension must be for a minimum of five Seasons (including the current Season and any [Option Year](https://cbaguide.com/contractanatomy/terms/options/)).

title: Raises
content:
Increases and decreases of up to 8% are permitted.

If starting Salary of the Rookie Scale Extension is based on percentage of Salary Cap, then the annual increase/decrease can be identified as a percentage of the starting [Salary](https://cbaguide.com/contractanatomy/terms/compensation/salary/).

title: Eligibility
content:
### Contract Length Determines Eligibility

Whether a Player is Extension eligible typically depends on the length of his current Contract and when it was signed.

| Contract Length | Eligibility                     |
| --------------- | ------------------------------- |
| 1 to 2 Years    | Not Eligible                    |
| 3 to 4 Years    | Second Anniversary of Signing\* |
| 5 to 6 Years    | Third Anniversary of Signing    |

\*Renegotiation Exception ‚Äì If Contract was a [Renegotiation](https://cbaguide.com/transactions/renegotiations/) increasing Player‚Äôs Salary by 10% or more, then eligibility is not until the third anniversary of signing.

‚ÄúFull Bird‚Äù Requirement ‚Äì A Player can only sign an Extension if at the end of the Contract he will qualify for [Full Bird Rights](https://cbaguide.com/thresholds/salarycap/#bird).

### Determining Signing Date and Years

If an Extension/Renegotiation is signed on October 2nd through the last day before the Regular Season, it‚Äôs treated as being signed on October 1st for Extension eligibility purposes.

Always include remaining Seasons of the Original Contract when calculating the amount of years in an Extension.

If the new Extension is extending a previously-signed Extension, then the number of Seasons used to calculate eligibility is the number of Seasons included in the most recent Extension.

title: When Extension Can be Signed
content:
### One Season Remaining

If only one Season remains on the Contract, the Extension can be signed anytime during the Regular Season.

* Exception ‚Äì A Designated Veteran Extension must still be signed before the start of the Regular Season.

### More than One Season Remaining

If more than one Season remains on the current Contract, then Veteran Extensions can only be signed between July 6th at 12:01 P.M. up to the date before the Regular Season begins.

title: Compensation
content:
A Player eligible for a Veteran Extension is typically limited to an increase in Compensation based upon the last Season of the existing Contract, subject to few exceptions.

Compensation is then split into different categories when calculating the increase limitation: [Salary](https://cbaguide.com/contractanatomy/terms/compensation/salary/) and [Performance Bonuses](https://cbaguide.com/contractanatomy/terms/compensation/incentivecompensation/#performance).

### The General 140% Increase

**Salary**

Unless one of the exceptions to the rule applies below, a Player‚Äôs starting salary in Year 1 of his extended term can be the _greater of_ (i) 140% of the [Regular Salary](https://cbaguide.com/contractanatomy/terms/compensation/regularsalary/) in the last year of his Contract, or (ii) 140% of the [EAPS](https://cbaguide.com/definitions/) for the Salary Cap Year in which the Extension is signed (or 140% EAPS less [Incentive Compensation](https://cbaguide.com/contractanatomy/terms/compensation/incentivecompensation/) if included in Extension).

**‚úçÔ∏è** **Salary Limitation Poses Issues for Underpaid Players**  
The 140% increase limitation poses risks for Players who are underpaid in their current Contract. If the 140% increase is still below market value, then the Team must allow the Player to reach Free Agency to sign the Player to a larger Contract, availing him to other bidders. Take, for example, Austin Reaves of the Lakers. In 2025-26, Reaves is earning $13.9 million in the final year of his Contract. The first year of his Extension is limited to $19.46 million, which is still below his market value. The Lakers will therefore have to allow him to reach Free Agency before trying to sign him to a larger Contract using Full Bird Rights.

**Incentive Compensation**

If the last Season of the original Contract included [Incentive Compensation](https://cbaguide.com/contractanatomy/terms/compensation/incentivecompensation/), then the first Season of the Extension can include 140% of the [Likely and Unlikely Bonuses](https://cbaguide.com/contractanatomy/terms/compensation/incentivecompensation/#performance), respectively, in the last Salary Cap Year covered by the original term (see below regarding Non-Performance Bonuses).

**üèÄ** **Gordon Signs Max Extension with Nuggets**  
In October 2024, Aaron Gordon signed an Extension with the Nuggets that starts in 2026-27\. His Extension included maximum increases for both his Base Salary and his Incentive Compensatation, broken down below:  
  
| Season  | Base Salary | IncentiveCompensation | IncreaseAmount |
| ------- | ----------- | --------------------- | -------------- |
| 2025-26 | $22,841,455 | $1,200,000            |                |
| 2026-27 | $31,978,037 | $1,680,000            | 140%           |
| 2027-28 | $34,536,280 | $1,814,400            | 8%             |
| 2028-29 | $37,094,523 | $1,948,800            | 8%             |

**Adjustment for Certain Bonuses**

When determining the Player‚Äôs maximum allowable [Salary](https://cbaguide.com/contractanatomy/terms/compensation/salary/) in a Veteran Extension, you add (i) bonuses for physical/academic achievement, and (ii) bonuses related to promotional appearances to _Regular Salary_, and exclude them from _Incentive Compensation_.

**Maximum Salary Limitation**

If 140% increase exceeds the Player‚Äôs [Maximum Salary](https://cbaguide.com/contractanatomy/terms/contractlimitations/), he will be reduced to his applicable Maximum Salary.

**üèÄ** **Luka Limited to Max Salary in Extension**  
In 2025, Luka Doncic signed a new Extension for his Maximum Salary of 30% of the Salary Cap. This is because a 140% salary in the final season of his existing contract would have exceeded the 30% maximum he is allowed.

### Designated Veteran Extension (the ‚ÄúSupermax‚Äù)

If a Player is eligible for the **Supermax**, then he can avoid the 140% limitation and sign for 30% to 35% of the Salary Cap.

**Supermax Eligibility**

A Player is eligible for the Supermax if the following elements are met:

1. Completed 7 or 8 YOS at time of signing Extension;
2. Has 1 or 2 Seasons remaining on Contract (including Option Year);
3. Remains on his first Team _or_ was traded during his first 4 Seasons;
4. Has achieved the [Higher Max Criteria](https://cbaguide.com/contractanatomy/terms/contractlimitations/#criteria) at the time of signing his Extension.

**üèÄ** **Losing Supermax Eligibility due to Trade**During the 2024-25 Season, Luka Doncic was traded from the Mavericks to the Lakers. This was his 7th year in the League. Because he did not remain on his original team, nor was he traded in his first four seasons he lost Supermax eligibility even though he reached the Higher Max Criteria.

**üèÄ** **Hitting Eligiblity in Time for Supermax**In the summer of 2023, Jaylen Brown was entering the final season of his Rookie Scale Extension and was extension eligible. Luckily for Brown he achieved Second-Team All-NBA in the 2022-2023 Season. As a result, he hit the Higher Max Criteria and was eligible for the Supermax with the Celtics.

**No Conditional Language for Supermax**

Unlike [Rookie Scale Extensions](#conditional), Veteran Extensions don‚Äôt allow conditional language for a Player to reach the Higher Maximum Criteria after the Extension is signed like the Rookie Scale Extension does. 

The Player, like Jaylen Brown above, must have reached the Higher Maximum Criteria prior to the signing of the Extension

**Trade Restriction of Supermax Contract**

Player  cannot be traded for 1 Year after signing Supermax.

### The Ten-Year Veteran Exception

If (i) a Player played for his current Team for 10+ Seasons and (ii) whose [Salary](https://cbaguide.com/contractanatomy/terms/compensation/salary/) declined in the final Season of his Contract, then his maximum allowable Salary can be the following:

The _greater of_ (i) 107.5% of the average of the [Regular Salaries](https://cbaguide.com/contractanatomy/terms/compensation/regularsalary/) for each Salary Cap Year covered by the original Contract beginning when it was entered into or extended, or (ii) 107.5% of the Regular Salary in the last Salary Cap Year covered by his original Contract.

If this amount is less than the 140% rule above, then the 140% rule can be applied instead.

title: Length
content:
A Veteran Extension other than a Supermax must be between 2 and 5 Seasons from the date it is signed.

Supermax Contracts must be for six Seasons from the date it‚Äôs signed.

title: Raises
content: Any Extension can be for up to 8% [annual increases/decreases](https://cbaguide.com/contractanatomy/terms/contractlimitations/#increases).

title: Trades Limiting Extension Terms
content:
### Extend-and-Trade

The above Salary, length and raises are not allowed when signing an Extension as part of a trade (i.e. an Extend-and-Trade).

Extend-and-Trade terms are limited to 120% of Prior [Salary](https://cbaguide.com/contractanatomy/terms/compensation/salary/), 4 Seasons in length and 5% raises.

Visit the [Extend-and-Trade](https://cbaguide.com/transactions/trades/signandtrade/#extend) page for full details.

### The Six-Month Prohibition

To prevent the possibility of extending a Player immediately before or after a Trade to workaround the Extend-and-Trade limitations, the following trade restrictions were put in place:

1. If a Player is acquired via Trade, the Team cannot sign the Player for more than 4 Seasons and 120% of his Prior Salary for six months.
2. And vice-versa, if a Player signs an Extension for more than 4 Seasons, 120% increase in Prior Salary, or 5% raises, then he cannot be traded for six months.

title: Options in Original Contract
content:
### Team and Player Options

An already existing [Option](https://cbaguide.com/contractanatomy/terms/options/) can be exercised or declined when effectuating an Extension, provided the eligibility requirements above are still met.

To do so, the Contract will be amended to simultaneously provide for the exercising or non-exercising of the Option along with the execution of the Extension.

If the Option is declined as part of the Extension, then the Extension must cover a minimum of two Seasons, _excluding_ Option Years.

**üèÄ** **Player Option Declined**In 2025, Luka Doncic declined his 2026-27 Player Option as part of his new Veteran Extension, which now began in 2026-27 and ran through 2028-29 with a new Player Option.

**üèÄ** **Player Option Exercised**In 2024, Aaron Gordon exercised his 2025-26 Player Option as part of his Veteran Extension. As a result, the extended term began in 2026-27 with a new Player Option in 2028-29.

### Early Termination Options (ETO‚Äôs)

A Contract that has been shortened by exercising an [ETO ](https://cbaguide.com/contractanatomy/terms/options/)cannot be extended.

If the Extension is signed prior to exercising the ETO, then it must be eliminated.

title: Signing Bonuses and Trade Bonuses
content:
### Signing Bonuses

An Extension can include a Signing Bonus, but the date when it becomes payable is limited. Visit the [Payment Arrangements](https://cbaguide.com/contractanatomy/terms/payment-arrangements/#signingbonusextensions) page for details.

### Trade Bonuses and Extensions

Trade Bonuses can be added, removed or adjusted in an Extension. Visit the [Trade Bonus](https://cbaguide.com/transactions/trades/tradebonus/) page for details.

title: Extend-and-Trade
content:
_See_ [Extend-and-Trade](https://cbaguide.com/transactions/trades/signandtrade/#extend) Rules here.

Renegotiations

 A **Renegotiation** is a limited method of increasing the current Season‚Äôs Salary for a Player, which can _only_ be accomplished using Cap Space. Renegotiations are typically executed to allow the Team to sign the Player to a larger Extension than what is permitted prior to the Renegotiation.

title: Dates of Eligibility
content: A Player‚Äôs Contract cannot be renegotiated from March 1st through June 30th.

title: Player Eligibility
content:
Only Player Contracts covering 4+ Seasons may be renegotiated.

Player becomes eligible on the third anniversary of the signing of the Contract, with the following exceptions:

1. Extension ‚Äì If the Original Contract was extended, then he is eligible on the third anniversary of the signing of the [Extension](https://cbaguide.com/transactions/extensions/).
2. Prior Renegotiation ‚Äì If the Original Contract was already renegotiated with an increase of 5% or more of [Salary](https://cbaguide.com/contractanatomy/terms/compensation/salary/)/[Incentive Compensation](https://cbaguide.com/contractanatomy/terms/compensation/incentivecompensation/), then he is eligible on the third anniversary of the Renegotiation.
3. Trade Bonus Amended ‚Äì If a [Trade Bonus](https://cbaguide.com/transactions/trades/tradebonus/) was waived/reduced, then the Player can‚Äôt renegotiate until six months from the Trade (or the dates above, if later).

title: Compensation
content:
### Increase in Compensation

The Renegotiation can include an increase in [Regular Salary](https://cbaguide.com/contractanatomy/terms/compensation/regularsalary/) and [Performance Bonuses](https://cbaguide.com/contractanatomy/terms/compensation/incentivecompensation/#performance) for the then-current Salary Cap Year.

The Renegotiation may provide for additonal Performance Bonuses that were not in the Original Contract.

The amount of Regular Salary and Performance Bonuses may not exceed the Team‚Äôs Cap Space at the time of Renegotiation.

### Decrease in Compensation

A Renegotiation cannot decrease a Player‚Äôs [Salary](https://cbaguide.com/contractanatomy/terms/compensation/salary/)/[Incentive Compensation](https://cbaguide.com/contractanatomy/terms/compensation/incentivecompensation/).

**üí°** **How to Lower Salary?**  
With one caveat, the CBA prohibits any ability for a Player and Team to agree to lower the Player‚Äôs already agreed-to Compensation in an existing Contract, even if they would like to do so as part of a longer Extension.  
  
The one caveat ‚Äì If there is an Option. The Option can be declined and lesser Compensation can take the place of that Option Year, which would be executed as part of an Extension. For example, Draymond Green declined his $27.5 million 2023-24 Player Option to sign a longer term contract. The contract reduced his 2023-24 Salary to $22.3 while agreeing to an Extension that would pay him more over the long-term (4 years, $100 million thorugh 2026-27).

### Renegotiations and Maximum Salary

The [Maximum Salary](https://cbaguide.com/contractanatomy/terms/contractlimitations/) rules apply, but a Player may _not_ qualify for an increase in percentage of the Salary Cap based upon hitting the [Higher Max Criteria](https://cbaguide.com/contractanatomy/terms/contractlimitations/#criteria).

title: Annual Raises
content:
Each category that is increased ([Regular Salary](https://cbaguide.com/contractanatomy/terms/compensation/regularsalary/), [Likely Bonuses](https://cbaguide.com/contractanatomy/terms/compensation/incentivecompensation/#performance) or [Unlikely Bonuses](https://cbaguide.com/contractanatomy/terms/compensation/incentivecompensation/#performance)), must be increased for each remaining Season in the Contract.

The [annual raises](https://cbaguide.com/contractanatomy/terms/contractlimitations/#increases) are limited to 8% for each category.

title: Signing Bonus Prohibited
content: [Signing](https://cbaguide.com/contractanatomy/terms/paymentarrangements/#signingbonus)[ Bonuses](https://cbaguide.com/contractanatomy/terms/paymentarrangements/#signingbonus) are prohited as part of a Renegotiation unless part of a Renegotiation-and-Extend, discussed below.

title: Generally
content:
If the Player is eligible for both a Renegotiation and an [Extension](https://cbaguide.com/transactions/extensions/), then both can be signed simultaneously as part of a Renegotiate-and-Extend.

**üí°** **Main Purpose of Renegotiate-and-Extend**  
In addition to the obvious fact that the Player will earn more money in the last year of his Original Contract, the Renegotiate-and-Extend provision provides flexibility for a Team in two common scenarios.  
  
Scenario #1 ‚Äì Increases Extension Offer  
Because the Extension rules limit most Extensions to a 140% increase of Prior Salary, a Team may not be able to offer a Player his actual value in an Extension if his Prior Salary is too low. A Renegotiation allows a Team to bump the last year of his Salary to increase the total amount offered in an Extension.  
  
This is the more common scenario used to extend Players without the risk of them going to Free Agency (e.g. Jaren Jackson, Jr. in 2025).  
  
Scenario #2 ‚Äì Pay More Up-Front to Clear Team Salary in the Future  
If a Team has Cap Space now, but knows other Extensions will significantly increase their Team Salary in the future, they can increase a Player‚Äôs Salary up-front and drop his Salary in future Seasons to lessen Team Salary for other signings. The Player will still earn the same amount, but will get more money up front. A win for both sides (e.g. Jonathan Isaac in 2024).

title: Decrease in Extended Term
content:
### Regular Salary

[Salary](https://cbaguide.com/contractanatomy/terms/compensation/salary/) less [Incentive Compensation](https://cbaguide.com/contractanatomy/terms/compensation/incentivecompensation/) in the first year can decrease by up to 40% of the Regular Salary the the last year of the Original Contract (as renegotiated).

**üèÄ** **Isaac‚Äôs Salary Reduced in Renegotiate-and-Extend**  
In 2024, Jonathan Isaac agreed to a Renegotiate-and-Extend with the Magic adding 4 Seasons to his Original Contract. The last year of his Original Contract increased from $17.4 million to $25 million. Year 2 then dropped from $25 million to $15 million, which is the maximum 40% decrease. While the Magic had plenty of Cap Space in 2024 to work with, the drop in Salary gives additional flexibility to plan for the Extensions of Franz Wagner and Paolo Banchero.

### Incentive Compensation

If there is [Incentive Compensation](https://cbaguide.com/contractanatomy/terms/compensation/incentivecompensation/) in the Original Contract and it was renegotiated, then Likely Bonuses and Unlikley Bonuses can each decrease by 40% in the first year of the extended term.

title: Trade Restrictions
content:
There is not a Renegotiate-and-Trade rule in the CBA.

A Player who signs a Renegotiation cannot be traded for six months.

Waivers

**Waiver** is the process of terminating a Player Contract before the term expires. A Waived Player‚Äôs Contract can be claimed by another Team, or the Contract will be terminated and he will become a UFA. If the Contract is terminated and the Player had Protected Compensation outstanding, then it becomes **Dead Salary** the Team is responsible to pay to the Player. They may elect to **Stretch** the Dead Salary over a longer period of time for Team Salary purposes.

title: The Waiver Process
Waiver Requests
content:
A Waiver Request cannot be withdrawn during the 48-hour Waiver process. He is either claimed or the Contract is terminated.

Both the [Roster Spot](https://cbaguide.com/eligibility/rosters/) and the Non-Guaranteed Salary are freed up immediately upon _request_ . This allows Teams to effectuate trades without having to wait the 48 hours.

[July Moratorium](https://cbaguide.com/calendar/) does not prohibit Requests or Claims.

[10-Day Contracts](https://cbaguide.com/contractanatomy/contracttypes/#tenday) do not go through the Waiver Process and are terminated immediately.

### Playoff Eligibility and Waiver

A Player must have been _requested_ to be waived by March 1st to remain eligible for the Playoffs in the current Season when signed by another Team.

* Exception ‚Äì Player is acquired by a Team whose [Active List](https://cbaguide.com/eligibility/rosters/) was reduced to 8 Players due to injury/illness.

title: Waiver Claim
content:
### Requirements

The Team must have an open [Roster Spot](https://cbaguide.com/eligibility/rosters/) and [Room](https://cbaguide.com/definitions/#room) to sign the Player.

The Team must pay a fee to the League when making a claim.

### Waiver Order

If multiple Teams claim a Player, the Team with the worst record wins the claim.

In the offseason and through November 30th of the Regular Season, use the prior Season‚Äôs record.

If Teams have an equal winning percentage, then the tiebreaker goes to the Team with the worst winning percentage among the tied Teams in regular season games played. If still tied, a coin toss determines the tiebreaker.

### Effect of Claim

The Claiming Team assumes the entire Contract, similar to a [Trade](https://cbaguide.com/transactions/trades/traderules/).

The Claiming Team cannot Trade the Player for 30 days during the season, or the first 30 days of next season if claimed in the offseason.

title: Partial Waivers
content: **Partial** **Waivers**\-where a Team will claim a Player but only agree to pay a certain portion of his guaranteed Salary-is only permitted as part of the Fitness-to-Play Panel process.

title: Re-Signing After Waivers
content:
If a Player is Traded and subsequently waived, the Sending Team cannot sign or claim the Player until the earlier of (i) 1 year following the date all conditions of the Trade were satisfied and (ii) July 1st following the last Season of the waived Contract.

If a Player and Team agree to a Buyout, then the Team cannot re-sign the Player until the later of (i) 1 year after the Contract was terminated and (ii) July 1st following the last Season of the Contract.

title: Calculating Dead Salary
content:
### Base Compensation

If he clears waivers, the Player is still owed his [Protected Compensation](https://cbaguide.com/contractanatomy/terms/compensationprotection/) for the remainder of the Contract (subject to any [Buyout](#buyout) agreed to, discussed below).

Unearned/unprotected [Base Compensation](https://cbaguide.com/contractanatomy/terms/compensation/basecompensation/) and any Bonuses are not due to the Player.

### The Universal ‚ÄúCutdown‚Äù Date

Any Contract that is terminated for ‚Äúlack of skill‚Äù from January 10th to the end of the Season is entitled to his full [Base Compensation](https://cbaguide.com/contractanatomy/terms/compensation/basecompensation/) for the Season.

Therefore, if a Team seeks to terminate the Contract prior to the [Salary](https://cbaguide.com/contractanatomy/terms/compensation/salary/) being fully guaranteed for the Season, the Team must allow the Player to clear waivers prior to January 10th (i.e. he must be cut on January 8th).

### Options and ETO‚Äôs

1. [ETO‚Äôs](https://cbaguide.com/contractanatomy/terms/options/) ‚Äì Counted as guaranteed salary;
2. [Team Options ](https://cbaguide.com/contractanatomy/terms/options/)‚Äì Not owed to the Player if cut prior to exercising Team Option;
3. [Player Options](https://cbaguide.com/contractanatomy/terms/options/) ‚Äì Depends on language in the Contract. See [Compensation Protection](https://cbaguide.com/contractanatomy/terms/compensationprotection/#option) page for details.

### Salary Calculation During Season

If the Player is waived during the Regular Season (before the universal guarantee date of January 10th), his Current Season‚Äôs salary is calculated as follows:

Calculating Dead Salary Midseason

**Step 1** ‚Äì Divide Base Compensation by the number of days in the Regular Season to obtain Per-Day Salary.

**Step 2** ‚Äì Multiply the Per-Day Salary by the number of days that have elapsed since he cleared waivers. This is the Player‚Äôs **Earned Compensation**.

**Step 3** ‚Äì If his Earned Compensation is greater than his Protected Compensation for the Current Season, then the Earned Compensation is the Team‚Äôs Dead Salary. If it is less, then the Team‚Äôs Dead Salary is the amount of his Protected Compensation.

**Base Compensation and the Minimum Salary Subsidy**

Note that Base Compensation does not factor in the [subsidization](https://cbaguide.com/contractanatomy/terms/compensation/salary/#oneyear) for a 1-Year Minimum Salary Player. Use the Minimum Salary applicable for the Player‚Äôs [YOS](https://cbaguide.com/definitions/#yos). In other words, a Player with 6 YOS who signs a 1-Year Minimum Contract will be subsidized to the 2 YOS Minimum Salary for Cap/Apron/Tax purposes. However, if he is waived you use the full amount of his [Minimum Salary](https://cbaguide.com/contractanatomy/terms/contractlimitations/).

**üèÄ** **Waiving a Minimum Salary with Compensation Protection**During the 2024-25 Season, the Timberwolves waived P.J. Dozier on December 28th, clearing waivers on December 30th. Dozier‚Äôs Base Compensation was $2,613,120 and his Contract was guaranteed for $1 million. 70 days had elapsed as of December 30th. **Step 1** ‚Äì $2,613,120 √∑ 174 (Regular Season Days) = $15,017 Per-Day Salary. **Step 2** ‚Äì $15,017 x 70 (days elapsed) = $1,051,255 Earned Compensation. **Step 3** ‚Äì Because his Earned Compensation was greater than the $1 million guaranteed Salary, Minnesota owed Dozier $1,051,255 in Dead Salary.

###

title: Stretching Salary
content:
### Payment vs. Effect on Team Salary

**Stretching** Salary means spreading the Dead Salary across twice the remaining Seasons, plus one more Season.

The actual [Payment Arrangement](https://cbaguide.com/contractanatomy/terms/paymentarrangements/#deadsalary) of the Dead Salary is automatically stretched.

For [Team Salary](https://cbaguide.com/thresholds/teamsalary/) purposes, the Team can elect whether to stretch the Dead Salary, or to keep the Dead Salary as it was originally allocated in the Contract.

**üèÄ** **To Stretch or Not to Stretch**Player is waived on August 1st for the 2025-26 season with $5 million for both 2025-26 and 2026-27\. Automatically, the Player will be _paid_ $2 million over the next five Seasons. The Team can then elect to (i) have $5 million in Dead Salary in 2025-26 and 2026-27, or (ii) lower the Dead Salary amount for those Seasons and spread it across the five Seasons in line with the stretch provision (the Team can also wait and stretch only the Second Season in a **Delayed Stretch** discussed below). 

### Calculating Stretched Dead Salary

**Election from July 1st to August 31st**

Dead Salary stretched equally for twice the amount of Remaining Seasons, plus one (including the Current Season).

**Election from September 1 through June 30th**

Any Dead Salary for the Current Season shall remain unchanged. Any Dead Salary for Future Seasons will be stretched equally for twice the amount of Remaining Seasons, plus one (not including the Current Season).

**üèÄ** **Bucks Waive-and-Stretch Lillard‚Äôs $112 million**In the 2025 offseason, the Bucks waived Lillard‚Äôs remaining $112,583,216 in guaranteed salary. Lillard had two Seasons remaining, which included his Player Option. The Bucks stretched his Dead Salary over the 5 Seasons for $22,516,603 each Season through 2029-30\. This helped clear cap space to sign Myles Turner in the same offseason.

### Delayed Stretch

The Team can elect to stretch the Dead Salary at any point through the term of the waived Contract until September 1st of the last Season.

**üèÄ** **Delaying the Stretch Election**Taking the ‚ÄúTo Stretch or Not to Stretch‚Äù Example above. The team can wait until the 2026 offseason, and elect a Delayed Stretch for only the 2026-27 Seson (election to be made prior to September 1st). This means that the $5 million in Dead Salary was on the books for the 2025-26 Seasons, and now the Team will stretch the remaining $5 million across three seasons at $1.66 million through 2028-29.

**üèÄ** **Delayed Stretch Before Rubio‚Äôs Final Season of Dead Salary**Rubio‚Äôs Buyout with the Cavaliers is discussed in detail below. After the Buyout, the Cavaliers elected to Stretch his 2024-25 Dead Salary of $1,274,015, which is stretched equally at $424,672 over 3 Seasons (twice the remaining seasons (1), plus one).

### Limitation on Stretch Election

A Team‚Äôs Stretched Salary can only make up 15% of the Salary Cap for a particular Season.

**üèÄ** **Suns stretch 15% of the Salary Cap in 2025-26**In the 2025 offseason, the Suns waived Bradley Beal‚Äôs Contract with $103,870,200 remaining in guaranteed Salary. The Suns already had stretched Salary from waivers in 2024 of Nassir Little ($3,107,143) and E.J. Liddell ($706,898). Beal had to agree to a buyout, reducing his guaranteed Salary to $96,917,050 to allow the Suns to stretch his Salary, which takes up 12.5% of the Salary Cap and keeping them right at 15% of the maximum Stretched Salary for the 2025-26 Season.

title: General Rule
content:
A **Buyout** is a method of the Team and Player agreeing to reduce the amount of the Player‚Äôs [Protected Compensation](https://cbaguide.com/contractanatomy/terms/compensationprotection/) in exchange for his release.

The Buyout agreement can include language limiting or eliminating the Team‚Äôs right to Set-Off.

**üèÄ** **Micic Agrees to Buyout and Signs Overseas**In 2025, Vasilije Micic was traded to the Bucks. Shortly after the trade, he agreed to a buyout, foregoing $6.1 million of his $8.1 million Protected Compensation. Shortly after the Buyout, Micic signed overseas to a 3-Year, $18 million Contract.

title: Buyouts and January 10th
content:
On January 10th all non-guaranteed [Base Compensation](https://cbaguide.com/contractanatomy/terms/compensation/basecompensation/) for the Season is fully guaranteed, so there is nothing to Buyout (unless the Player has future guaranteed Seasons). However, a Player can still agree to reduce the guaranteed Salary if he wants out of his current Contract to sign with a new Team.

**üèÄ** **Starks Argues Right to Forego Guaranteed Salary**In 2000, John Starks wanted to forego his guaranteed Salary after the January 10th guarantee date, but it was unclear if he was able to do so. The case went to an arbitrator that ruled that a Team and Player can agree that the Player can forego his guaranteed Salary after January 10th. (Note it was too late for Starks by the time the ruling came out, but blazed a new path for Players seeking to forego guaranteed money for a Playoff Team).

title: Allocation of Buyout
content:
If the Player and Team agreed on a [Buyout](#buyout) (discussed below), then the total amount that was reduced will be reallocated pro rata over then-current and remaining Salary Cap Years based on the remaining [Protected Compensation](https://cbaguide.com/contractanatomy/terms/compensationprotection/) in each Salary Cap Year.

This math is without any [Stretch](#stretch) election, discussed above.

Allocating Buyout Amount

**Step 1 ‚Äì Calculate the total Dead Salary _after_ Buyout**  
First, determine how much of the remaining Protected Compensation (i.e. Dead Salary) after the Buyout. This is the **New Dead Salary**.

**Step 2 ‚Äì Calculate the Percentage of Original Dead Salary for Each Season**  
For all Seasons with remaining Protected Compensation, add together _Original_ Dead Salary (prior to Buyout) and find the percentage of each individual Season. This is the **Yearly Percentage**.

In other words, if the total Dead Salary prior to Buyout is $10 million, and Year 1 has Dead Salary of $2 million, then the Yearly Percentage for Year 1 is 20%.

**Step 3 ‚Äì Reallocate New Dead Salary using Yearly Percentage**  
For each Remaining Season, multiply the New Dead Salary amount by the Yearly Percentage.

**üèÄ** **Rubio‚Äôs Buyout Allocated Pro Rata**  
In January 2024, Rubio agreed to a Waiver and a Buyout, reducing his Dead Salary from $10,396,342 to $4,996,342\. His remaining Dead Salary was originally as follows:  
  
2023-24: $6,146,342  
2024-25: $4,250,000  
Total: $10, 396,342  
  
**Step 1 ‚Äì Calculate the total Dead Salary _after_ Buyout**  
The New Dead Salary is $4,996,342 million  
  
**Step 2 ‚Äì Calculate the Percentage of Dead Salary for Each Season**  
The Yearly Percentage for 2023-24 is 59.12% (6,146,342 √∑ 10,396,342 = 59.12) and for 2024-25 is 40.88% (4,250,000 √∑ 10,396,342 = 40.88).  
  
**Step 3 ‚Äì Reallocate new Dead Salary using Yearly Percentage**  
For 2023-24, the new Dead Salary after Buyout is $3,722,327 (0.5912 √ó 4,996,342 = $3,722,327), and for 2024-25 is $1,274,015 (0.4088 √ó 4,996,342 = $1,274,015).

title: Set-Off
content:
If a Player (i) is waived by one Team (**Prior Team**), (ii) is owed Dead Salary by his Prior Team, and (iii) signs a new Contract with a new Team (**Subsequent** **Team**) during the term of the original Contract, then the Prior Team may be entitled to a **Set-Off**, reducing the amount owed in Dead Salary to the Player.

The **Set-Off Amount** is calculated using the amount of Compensation the Player earns in his **Subsequent Contract** and adjusting using the calculation below (the Prior Team can require the Player provide evidence of the Compensation earned in his Subsequent Contract).

title: Calculating Set-Off Amount
content:
Below are the steps for calculating the Set-Off Amount:

Calculating Set-Off Amount

**Step 1 ‚Äì Calculate Earned Compensation**

Calculate the total Compensation earned by the Player during the Salary Cap Year from the Subsequent Contract to find the **Earned Compensation**.

**Step 2 ‚Äì Subtract Minimum Salary**

Subtract the following amount from the Earned Compensation:

1. If Rookie when waived: Subtract Minimum Salary for 0 YOS at the time the initial Contract was terminated.
2. If Veteran when waived: Subtract the Minimum Salary for 1 YOS at the time the initial Contract was terminated.

**Step 3 ‚Äì Cut in Half**

If Step 2 is a positive number, then multiply that amount by 50% to find the Set-Off Amount.

### Deferred Compensation Adjustment

If the Dead Salary is unearned [Deferred Compensation](https://cbaguide.com/contractanatomy/terms/paymentarrangements/#deferred) covering the term of the original Contract, then the Set-Off Amount is discounted by the [Prime Rate](https://cbaguide.com/contractanatomy/terms/paymentarrangements/#loans) at the time the agreement for Deferred Compensation was made.

**‚úçÔ∏è** **Set-Off Amount, Allocation and Team Salary**  
Note the difference between calculating the Set-Off Amount, how the Set-Off is allocated, and how it effects Team Salary. Each are treated differently.  
1. Set-Off Amount ‚Äì Calculated based on the term of the original Contract (regardless of any stretching of payments).
2. Allocation ‚Äì Once the Set-Off amount is known, is it equally spread across the stretched payments equally.
3. Team Salary ‚Äì Effect on Team Salary is solely dependent on if the Team elected to stretch the Dead Salary.

title: Allocation of Set-Off
content: Once the Set-Off Amount is calculated, is it allocated on an equal basis over the [Mandatory Stretch Provision](https://cbaguide.com/contractanatomy/terms/paymentarrangements/#deadsalary).

title: Effect on Team Salary
content:
The Set-Off Amount will operate in line with the Team‚Äôs election to stretch Dead Salary.

If the Dead Salary is stretched, then the Dead Salary is reduced the same as the Set-Off Payments above. 

If the Dead Salary is not stretched, then the Set-Off Amount will apply to the applicable Salary Cap Year.

**üèÄ** **Waiver and Set-Off Calculation of Stretched Salary**Player has Dead Salary of $3 million from his 2023-24 Salary. The Team receives a Set-Off amount for the 2023-24 Season of $600,000\. The Dead Salary is stretched over three seasons at $1 million per Season. The Set-Off reduction is $200,000 across the three Seasons. If the Team elected to stretch the Dead Salary for Cap purposes, then the Dead Salary will also be reduced in the same manner

**üèÄ** **3-Year Contract Waived**Player has guaranteed Salary from 2023-24 through 2025-26 of his Contract for $9 million ($3 million each Season). The Player clears waivers on September 7, 2023, and signs a new Contract with the Second Team for years 2023-24 and 2024-25\. The First Team has a set-off right of $600k for 2023-24 and 2024-25 (and nothing for year 3 as the Second Contract does not run through 2025-26). The Player‚Äôs Dead Salary for 2023-24 is reduced to $2.4 million and is paid in accordance with the Contract (no stretch because it is after 8/31). The Player has $6 million remaining Dead Salary for 2024-25 and 2025-26, which is reduced by the $600,000, totaling $5.4 million. The $5.4 million Dead Salary payments are then stretched across five Seasons (twice the remaining seasons, plus one) at $1.08 million. If the Team stretched its Cap Hit, then the Cap Hit will be reduced in line at $1.08 million. If the Team did not elect to stretch the Cap Hit, then the Cap Hit for Year 2 would be $2.4 million and 2025-26 would be $3 million.

**üèÄ** **Another Contract Signed in Year 3**Taking the same facts as the example above, but a Third Team signs the Player on October 1, 2025, and assume that the First Team is entitled to a $500,000 Set-Off Amount for 2025-26 as a result. The $500,000 Set-Off Amount would be allocated across the remaining four seasons at $125,000 per Season, reducing the $1.08 million yearly Dead Salary to $955,000 from 2025-26 through 2028-29.

title: Waiver of Set-Off Right
content: The Team can waive or reduce its right to a Set-Off as part of a [Buyout](#buyout) agreement (discussed above).

title: Non-NBA Team and Set-Off Rights
content:
The right to Set-Off also applies when the Second Team is a **Non-NBA Team**.

Compensation can include any non-cash compensation provided to a Player as identified within the CBA.

If the Player is paid by the Non-NBA Team on a net-of-tax basis, then his Compensation for the year is to be divided by 0.65 before beginning Step 1 above, unless the Player shows that taxes were not paid or exceed the actual amount paid.

A Team is not required to enforce its Set-Off right against a Player who signed with a non-NBA Team.

title: Unrecouped Set-Offs
content:
If the Prior Team cannot deduct enough from ongoing payments to satisfy the Set-Off Amount, then the Prior Team can direct the Subsequent Team to withhold payment and pay the unrecouped amount to the Prior Team.

If there is still not enough to satisfy the Set-Off Amount, then the League and NBPA will work out an agreement.

title: Multiple Set-Off Rights
content:
If the Player was waived multiple times resulting in more than one Team with Set-Off rights during a Salary Cap Year, then the initial Prior Team will take priority in recouping the Set-Off Amount, followed by the following Teams with Set-Off rights in succession.

Trade Rules

title: Generally
Roster Spot Requirement
content:
If a Team is acquiring more Players than it is sending out, then the Team must have an open [Roster Spot](https://cbaguide.com/eligibility/rosters/) to absorb the additional Player(s) _prior to executing the Trade_.

**‚úçÔ∏è** It‚Äôs important to note this rule applies even if a Team is going to waive a a Player immediately after acquiring the Player in the Trade. There must still be an open Roster Spot for the Player to first place him on the Roster prior to waiving him.

Note that a Team can request a Player to be [waived](https://cbaguide.com/transactions/waivers/) and the roster spot will be opened before he clears waivers (they don‚Äôt have to wait).

title: Tradeable Assets
content:
It‚Äôs important to note what counts as an ‚Äúasset‚Äù in a Trade. This becomes particulary important in 3+ Team Trades when the [Touch Rule](#touch) comes into play and Teams just want to send _something_ to another Team to satisfy the rule.

What is a Tradeable Asset depends on whether it‚Äôs a 2-team Trade or 3+ Trade.

**Two-Team Trades**

Must send _and_ receive at least one of the following:

1. Player Contracts;
2. Draft Pick (protected up to 55 picks);
3. Draft rights to an **NBA Prospect**;
4. Swap Rights;
5. Cash-in-Trade (must be $110,000).

**3+ Team Trade**s

Must send _and/or_ receive one of the following from two or more Teams:

1. Player Contract;
2. Draft Pick _that actually conveys_ (can‚Äôt extinguish);
3. Draft Rights to an NBA Prospect;
4. Cash-in-Trade (must be $1,100,000 cash).

**NBA Prospect**

Defined as a Player (i) with a reasonable possibility of signing an NBA Contract during his career, or (ii) a starter/rotation Player in a reputable professional league.

Shall automatically be deemed an NBA Prospect if drafted in one of the three previous drafts.

Shall automaticaly be deemed a contributor in a reputable professional league if drafted in one of the five previous drafts.

**Conditioned Draft Pick Time Limitation**

A conditional Draft Pick will _not_ be considered a tradeable asset if the following elements are met:

1. Conditional pick is conveyed after 6:00 P.M. E.T. on the day prior to the first day of the Regular Season;
2. The conditional pick is for the Draft Immediately following the Regular Season; and
3. The obligation to convey the pick is extinguished if not conveyed in the upcoming Draft.

**üèÄ** **Time Limitation Extinguishes Tradeable Asset**  
Team A trades its 2026 2nd Round Pick to Team B, provided that such pick is not among the top 55 picks in the 2026 Draft. If it falls in the top 55 picks, then Team A‚Äôs obligation to convery a 2nd Round Pick is extinguished.  
  
If the Trade is consummated after 6:00 P.M. E.T. on the day prior to the start of the Regular Season, then this is not considered a tradeable asset and won‚Äôt satisfy the Touch Rule.

title: The Touch Rule
content:
When three or more teams are included in a Trade, each team involved in the Trade must **touch** at least two other teams.

A **touch** is either sending or receiving one of the tradeable assets listed in the list above.

**üèÄ** **Two Hypotheticals Showing How the Touch Rule Works**  
  
Hypothetical #1  
  
Team A trades a Player Z to Team B. Team B trades a 2028 1st round pick to Team A. Team B trades a Player Y to Team C to have enough outgoing Trade Salary to satisfy a Traded Player Exception.  
  
This would _not_ satisfy the Touch Rule.  
Team A: Touching Team B, but _not_ Team C;  
Team B: Touching Team A and Team C, satisfying the Touch Rule;  
Team C: Touch Team A, but _not_ Team B.  
  
 

  
Hypothetical #2  
  
The same trade as above, but now Team C sends a protected 2029 2nd round pick to Team A in addition to all other trade terms.  
  
This now satisfies the Touch Rule.  
Team A: Touching Team B and Team C;  
Team B: Touching Team A and Team C;  
Team C: Touching Team A and Team B.  
  
 

Example 1 one does _not_ satisfy the touch Rule as each Team only touches one of the other Teams:

Team A: Received an asset from Team B, sen

In Example 2, Team C is now sending an asset back to A. Now the Trade _does_ satisfy the Touch Rule, as each Team is touching the other.

title: Draft Picks Generally
content:
Note that the trading of Draft Picks is different than trading the [Draft Rights](https://cbaguide.com/eligibility/draftrules/) to a Player. Draft Rights are attached to a Player that has been drafted, but is not yet signed.

Trading future Draft Picks requires the Team to identify the specific year of the pick‚Äìwith the exception of pick protection contingencies‚Äìand the Team must already hold the right to the pick (i.e. cannot identify a pick as one that may be acquired in the future).

title: Pick Protections
content:
### Pick Protections Generally

Teams may make the conveyance of a pick contingent on where the pick is ordered in the Draft, called pick **protection**.

If a pick does not convey due to protections, additional contingencies can be added for the conveyance of a different pick or picks in the future, so long as specific years are identified.

**üèÄ** **Warriors Pick turns to 2nd if the 1st is Not Conveyed**  
As part of a Trade, the Warriors conveyed to the Wizards its 2030 1st Round Pick, protected if it is picks 1 through 20\. If it is picks 1 through 20, then the Warriors will instead convey a 2030 2nd Round pick to the Wizards.

### Protections and the Stepien Rule

All protections must still satisfy the [Stepien Rule](#stepien), discussed in more detail below.

### Protecting an Acquired Pick

A Team may add protections to a Draft Pick it had acquired from another Team in a prior Trade, subject to the following: 

1. The Team must hold the Draft Pick unconditionally; or
2. The Team initially held the Draft Pick unconditionally, but entered into a separate Trade that had added pick protections.

**üèÄ** **Adding Pick Protections to Different Team‚Äôs Pick**  
For example, Team A acquires the 2029 2nd Round Draft Pick from Team B unconditionally. Then conveys it in the following way: ‚ÄúTeam A conveys a 2029 2nd Round Draft Pick (Team B‚Äôs own) to Team C, provided that it is not among picks 31-45.‚Äù  
  
In a subsequent Trade, the pick is conveyed in the following way: ‚ÄúTeam A conveys a 2029 2nd Round Pick (Team B‚Äôs Own) to Team D, provided that it is not among picks 46-60.‚Äù

title: Deferral Options
content:
One or both Teams to a Trade may be permitted to exercise a one-time option to **defer** the conveyance or the receipt of a pick _for one year only_.

**üèÄ** **Pelicans Received Deferral Right to Lakers Pick**  
In 2019, as part of the Anthony Davis Trade, the Pelicans received the right to the Lakers‚Äô 2024 1st Round Pick, with an additional right to defer that right until 2025\. The Pelicans did indeed defer the pick until 2025.

Both deferral and pick protections cannot be used at the time time.

title: The ‚ÄúStepien‚Äù Rule
content:
### The 7-Year Rule

Both First and Second Round Picks can only be traded no later than the 7th Draft following the date of the Trade.

**‚úçÔ∏è** The new set of Draft Picks triggers immediately upon the conclusion of the NBA Draft. Therefore, immediately upon the conclusion of the 2026 NBA Draft, Teams will then be permitted to Trade their 2033 picks.

### Missing Consecutive 1st Round Picks

A Team must never have the _possibility_ to not have a First Round Pick in two consecutive Seasons. Therefore, if a protection creates the possibility, then it is prohibited.

A Team may own another Team‚Äôs Draft Pick to satisfy the Stepien Rule.

**üèÄ** **Suns Own Another Pick to Satisfy Stepien Rule**  
As of the 2025 Offseason, the Suns no longer have their own 2026 or 2027 First Round Picks. However, because they own the least favorable First of Utah, Cleveland and Minnesota in 2026, the Stepien Rule is satisfied.

### Conditional Language to Satisfy Stepien Rule

If it is unclear if/when a Draft Pick is going to be conveyed because of pick protections, then the following language can be used to satisfy the Stepien Rule:

* ‚ÄúTeam A conveys its own 1st Round Pick to Team B in the second Draft following the Draft in which Team A is required under the terms of \[a prior trade\] to convey its 1st Round Pick to \[Team involved in prior trade\].‚Äù

However, a Team can only have two of these types of conveyances in effect at one time. 

The language is not permitted if the year of the conveyance could occur in violation of the 7-Year Rule.

title: Cash-in-Trade Generally
content:
A Team can send and receive 5.15% of the Salary Cap as Cash-in-Trade each Salary Cap Year ($7,964,320 for 2025-2026).

Each amount that is sent and received are accounted for separately and added on throughout the Season (i.e. it is not the ‚Äúnet‚Äù amount sent and received).

**üèÄ** Team sends $3,000,000 in Cash in one Trade and receives $4,000,000 in another Trade. The Team has $4,964,320 left to send in Cash, and $3,964,320 left to receive in Cash.

Cash-in-Trade only effects the owner‚Äôs bottom line and has no effect on [Team Salary](https://cbaguide.com/thresholds/teamsalary/).

title: Conditional Cash-in-Trade
content:
When Cash-in-Trade is included in a Trade as an alternative to the conveyance of a potential Draft Pick, then the accounting for the Cash-in-Trade is for the year the Trade was _consummated_, not when the cash was _exchanged_.

**üèÄ** **Conditional Cash-in-Trade in 2025 Exchanges in 2026**  
For example, Team A and Team B agree to a Trade where Team B send Player to Team A. Team A agrees to send a 2026 1st Round Pick to Team B, but it is conditional on not being a lottery pick. If it is a lottery pick, then Team A instead gives $5 million to Team B. Although the money would be exchanged in 2026, the $5 million Cash-in-Trade would be accounted as sent and received in 2025.

If the conditional Draft Pick is subsequently traded again, you again account for the Cash-in-Trade at the time of the Trade.

**üèÄ** **Conditional Pick is Traded Again**  
Taking the example above, Team B then takes the conditional Draft Pick and trades it to Team C in 2025\. Team B now has lowered the amount it can convey by $5 milllion and Team C has lowered the amount it can receive by $5 million. Nothing changes from the first Trade, meaning Team A still lowers the amount it can convey by $5 million and Team B lowered the amount it can receive by $5 million.

title: Payment of Bonuses
content: Depending on the type of bonus, the Sending Team or Receiving Team will be responsible for payment, which may be different than how Bonuses affect T[eam Salary](https://cbaguide.com/thresholds/teamsalary/) (i.e. one Team may be responsible for paying a bonus while it‚Äôs added to the Team Salary of the other Team).

title: Signing Bonus
content: If a [Signi](https://cbaguide.com/contractanatomy/terms/paymentarrangements/)[n](https://cbaguide.com/contractanatomy/terms/paymentarrangements/#signingbonus)[g Bonus](https://cbaguide.com/contractanatomy/terms/paymentarrangements/) is provided in a Contract as part of a [Sign-and-Trade](https://cbaguide.com/transactions/trades/signandtrade/), then it is the responsibility of the Receiving Team. Any payment of the Signing Bonus by the Sending Team is considered a Cash-in-Trade and is governed by those rules.

title: Performance Bonus
content:
Any [Performance Bonus](https://cbaguide.com/contractanatomy/terms/compensation/incentivecompensation/#performance) earned is considered the responsibility of the Receiving Team to pay.

The Teams can agree that the Sending Team pay all or a portion of the Performance Bonus, but any payment by the Sending Team is considered Cash-in-Trade and is subject to those rules above, and is accounted for at the time of the Trade, _not_ when the Bonus is earned.

**üèÄ** **Agreeing to Performance Bonus**  
For example, Team A trades Player to Team B. Player has several performance bonuses in his contract reaching a total of $1 million. Team B is responsible for the payment of these Bonuses. Team A agrees to pay 25% of the Bonuses. Therefore, $250,000 is reduced from Team A‚Äôs allowable conveyance of Cash-in-Trade at the time of the Trade, and $250,000 is reduced from Team B‚Äôs allowable receipt of Cash-in-Trade at the time of the Trade, irrespective if the Player achieves the performance benchmarks.

title: Other Incentive Compensation
content:
For other types of [Incentive Compensation](https://cbaguide.com/contractanatomy/terms/compensation/incentivecompensation/) (i.e. conditioning, academic achievement, extra promo appearances), the Team that rostered the Player when the Bonus was earned is responsible for payment.

Similar to Performance Bonuses, the Teams can alter the [payment arrangement](https://cbaguide.com/contractanatomy/terms/paymentarrangements/), subject to the Cash-in-Trade rules.

title: Trade Bonus
content:
Trade Bonuses are paid by the Sending Team, but are added as [Team Salary](https://cbaguide.com/thresholds/teamsalary/) to the Receiving Team (visit the [Trade Bonus](https://cbaguide.com/transactions/trades/tradebonus/) page to view how the Trade Bonus is calculated).

Again, Teams can agree to a different payment arrangement of the Trade Bonus, subject to the Cash-in-Trade rules.

title: Options ‚Äì Conditioned to Trade
content: The Player and Sending Team can agree to amend a Contract to exercise or not exercise an [Option](https://cbaguide.com/contractanatomy/terms/options/) provided that the Contract is traded within 48 hours of executing the amendment.

title: Effect on Bird Rights
content:
Generally, when a Player is Traded, the Receiving Team retains the same [Bird Rights](https://cbaguide.com/thresholds/salarycap/#bird) the Sending Team had.

**üèÄ** **Siakim‚Äôs Bird Rights Acquired by Pacers, Used to Sign in Free Agency**  
During the 2023-24 season, the Raptors traded Pascal Siakim to the Pacers. Since the Raptors had his Full Bird Rights, they transferred to the Pacers in the trade. That summer when Siakim became an Unrestricted Free Agent, the Pacers used Full Bird Rights to sign Siakim over the Salary Cap to a maximum contract at 30% of the Salary Cap.

Exception ‚Äì Bird Rights do _not_ transfer and he is treated as if signing as a Free Agent if the following elements are met:

1. Signs a 1-year contract (excluding any Option Year);
2. Would be a Full Bird or Early Bird Free agent under the Contract after completing such Contract; and
3. Is traded to a new Team without exercising any applicable Option for the second year.

**‚úçÔ∏è** **Automatic No Trade Clause Created**  
Because of this downgrade in Bird Rights, the Player receives an [Automatic No Trade Clause](#automatic) (oftentimes called an ‚ÄúImplicit‚Äù No Trade Clause) upon the signing of his Contract, unless waived.

title: Limitations on Extensions
content:
If a Team acquires a Player they must wait 6 months before signing him to an [Extension](https://cbaguide.com/transactions/extensions/) that (i) covers 5 Seasons, (ii) provides for increases/decreases greater than 5%, or (iii) [Renegotiates](https://cbaguide.com/transactions/renegotiations/) his current Contract.

**‚úçÔ∏è** **Rule Avoids a Workaround**  
This is to avoid working around CBA restrictions. [Extend-and-Trade](https://cbaguide.com/transactions/signandtrade/#extend) rules limit signing a Player to 5 Seasons and 5% raises. This rule restricts the ‚Äúhandshake deal‚Äù where the Player gets traded and then immediately signs to an Extension with more favorable terms.

title: Team Salary and Trades
content:
The Receiving Team will acquire the entire [Salary](https://cbaguide.com/contractanatomy/terms/compensation/salary/) for the current Season and future Seasons of the Player‚Äôs Contract in the Trade.

The current Season‚Äôs Salary is _not_ prorated if the Player is traded midway through the Season.

title: Resigning a Traded/Waived Player
content: If a Team trades a Player and the acquiring Team subsequently [waives](https://cbaguide.com/transactions/waivers/) the player, the Sending Team can‚Äôt sign him to a new Contract until the _earlier of_: (i) 1 year following the date all conditions to the Trade were satisfied or (ii) the July 1 following the last Season of the player‚Äôs Contract.

title: Existing Financial Obligations of Sending Team
content:
Prior to the the assignment of any Player Contract, a Team must divest itself of any financial arrangements with the Player other than any [Loans](https://cbaguide.com/contractanatomy/terms/paymentarrangements/#loans) or [Compensation](https://cbaguide.com/contractanatomy/terms/compensation/) earned prior to assignment.

The Sending Team will be responsible for paying Salary through the day of the assignment unless he dresses for the Receiving Team on that day.

title: Trade of Exhibit 10 Contracts
content: If (i) a Team has a G League Affiliate, (ii) acquires by assignment an [Exhibit 10 Contract](https://cbaguide.com/contractanatomy/contracttypes/#exhibit10), (iii) the Contract has a Conversion Protection Amount, but not an [Exhibit 10 Bonus](https://cbaguide.com/contractanatomy/contracttypes/#exhibit10), then the Contract is deemed to include an Exhibit 10 Bonus in an amount equal to the Conversion Protection Amount.

title: Stacking Minimum Contracts
content: In certain scenarios, a Team is limited in the amount of Minimimum Contracts it can send out in an unbalanced Trade. This is addressed in the [Traded Player Exception](https://cbaguide.com/transactions/trades/tpe/#stacking) page.

title: Publicly Demanding a Trade
content: Any Player or agent who publicly expresses their desire to be traded shall be subject to a fine and/or suspension, with a maximum fine of $150,000.

title: Express No Trade Clause
content:
A Contract may include a No Trade Clause _only if_ the Player (i) has 8 [YOS](https://cbaguide.com/definitions/#yos) and (ii) has rendered 4+ YOS for the Team he‚Äôs entering into the Contract with.

If so, the Contract may contain a prohibition or limitation of such Team‚Äôs right to trade the Contract to another NBA Team.

title: Automatic No Trade Clause
content:
A Player receives an Automatic No Trade Clause (oftentimes referred to as an ‚ÄúImplicit‚Äù No Trade Clause), thus requiring his consent to be traded, if his Bird Rights would be reduced as a result of the Trade. 

The Player may elect to waive the Automatic No Trade Clause at the time of signing (or anytime during the life of the Contract).

**üèÄ** **Russell Waived Automatic No Trade Clause with Lakers**  
In the 2023 offseason, D‚ÄôAngelo Russell signed a 2-year, $37.4 million Contract with the Lakers. His Contract had a Player Option. Therefore, if traded he would subject to a reduction in his Bird Rights. Russell elected to waive his Automatic No Trade Clause at the time he signed the Contract. He was eventually traded to Brooklyn during the 2024-25 Season.

**Bird Rights Reduction**

[Bird](https://cbaguide.com/thresholds/salarycap/#bird)[ Rights](https://cbaguide.com/thresholds/salarycap/#bird) are downgraded if the following elements are met:

1. Signs a 1-year contract (excluding any [Option Year](https://cbaguide.com/contractanatomy/terms/options/));
2. Would be a Full Bird or Early Bird Free agent under the Contract after completing such Contract; and
3. Is traded to a new Team without exercising any applicable Option for the second year.

**üèÄ** **Thomas Receives Automatic No Trade Clause with Qualifying Offer**  
During the 2025 offseason, Cam Thomas was a Restricted Free Agent with the Nets. Reports indicated that Thomas was offered a 2-year deal and a 1-year deal for more money if he waived his Automatic No Trade Clause. Thomas opted to sign his $5.9 million Qualifying Offer to keep his No Trade Clause in place, ensure his Bird Rights were retained with the Nets, and allow himself to choose his destination if traded during the Season.

title: Date Restrictions
content:
### July Moratorium

Trades cannot be made during the [July Moratorium](https://cbaguide.com/calendar/) from July 1st through July 6th.

### Trade Deadline

**Trade Deadline Date**

February 5, 2026

**Trade Deadline Rule**

No Trades can be executed from the second Thursday before the All-Star Game until after the Team‚Äôs Regular Season ends.

Playoff Teams cannot trade any Player on its Playoff Roster until the Team is eliminated from the Playoffs, but can Trade any other assets after the Regular Season.

**üèÄ** **Pacers Make Trade During Playoffs**  
During the 2025 Playoffs while making their run to the NBA Finals, the Pacers executed a Trade with the Pelicans, sending the Draft Rights to Mojave King and its 2025 1st Round Pick to the Pelicans in exchange for a return of its own 1st Round Pick in 2026\. Because King was not on the Playoff Roster, the Pacers could trade him while still in the Playoffs.

### Entering Option Year

If a Contract _could_ be the last season of a Player‚Äôs Contract based on the exercise or non-exercise of the Contract (Option or ETO), then the Player cannot be traded after the Regular Season unless the [Option](https://cbaguide.com/contractanatomy/terms/options/) is exercised or the [ETO](https://cbaguide.com/contractanatomy/terms/options/) is declined.

Note an Option can be exercised as a condition to being traded, [as discussed above](#option).

**üèÄ** **Porzingis Exercises Option for Trade to Celtics**  
In June 2023, Kristaps Porzingis had a pending Player Option for the 2023-24 Season with the Wizards. The Wizards could not trade him with the pending Option. Porzingis exercised his Player Option to allow the Wizards and Celtics to execute the three-team trade with the Grizzlies.

### Sign-and-Trades

Any [Sign-and-Trade](https://cbaguide.com/transactions/trades/signandtrade/) must be completed prior to the Regular Season (for visit the [Sign-and-Trade](https://cbaguide.com/transactions/trades/signandtrade/) page for all rules on Sign-and-Trades).

### Draft Picks

The deadline for trading the current Season‚Äôs Draft Picks is 2:00 P.M. ET on the day of the Draft.

Once the Draft begins, the Teams can begin trading the [Draft Rights](https://cbaguide.com/eligibility/draftrules/) to the Players that are drafted.

Lottery picks cannot be traded from 6:00 P.M. ET the day before the Draft Lottery until the Draft Lottery concludes.
