title: Trade Call
content:
Below are the steps for completing a Trade:

1. Notify the League at least two hours before an impending Trade, if possible. League must be notified by 6:00 P.M. ET on Friday to perform a **Trade Call** on the weekend, otherwise it must wait until Monday (same rule applies for holidays).
2. Prior to the Trade Call, the parties exchange necessary health information.
3. All terms and conditions of the Trade are disclosed and agreed to during a conference call with the League.
4. Follow up email confirming the terms will be sent by the Teams to the League.
5. League will send an email confirming all conditions required for Trade to be consummated.

title: Physical Exam Contingency
content:
Any Trade can be conditioned upon the Player passing a physical examination.

**üèÄ** **Williams Fails Physical; Trade Nixed**  
In 2024, Mark Williams was traded to the Lakers from the Hornets. However, he failed his physical exam, and as a result the Lakers rescinded the Trade.  

Sometimes, rather than cancelling the Trade, Teams will adjust the terms based on the results of a physical examination.

**üèÄ** **Blazers remove 2nd Round Picks for Holiday Trade**  
In 2025, the Blazers initially had an agreement to send Anfernee Simons and two 2nd Round Picks to the Celtics for Jrue Holiday. After poor results from Holiday‚Äôs physical exam, the Blazers and Celtics agreed that the 2nd Round Picks would be dropped from the agreement.  
  
Note that the Williams Trade above had no chance of altering the Trade because it was made right at the deadline. Once the physical exam results came back, they were past the Trade Deadline and therefore couldn‚Äôt alter the terms and execute a new Trade.

title: Trade of Team Personnel
content:
The Trade of Team Personnel (e.g. a coach or G.M.) is permitted, but is limited to the Trade of future Draft Picks or cash, and is subject to the rules that apply to such Trades.

**üèÄ** **Rivers Traded to the Clippers**  
In 2013, the Celtics agreed to release head coach Doc Rivers from his current Contract to allow him to sign with the Clippers, in exchange for a 2015 1st Round Pick.

Traded Player Exceptions

 If a Team is over the Salary Cap, the only way a Trade is permitted is if it fits into an available **Trade Player Exception (TPE)**. Different TPE‚Äôs vary in trade flexibility and avilablility based on applicable Apron Restrictions.

title: Generally
content:
When executing a Trade, it is important to see where the Team lands _after_ the Trade is executed. If the Team is over the Salary Cap, then a **Traded Player Exception** (**TPE**) is required to execute the Trade (if below the Salary Cap, no Exception is needed).

There are four different types of TPE‚Äôs. A TPE is only available if the Team‚Äôs Apron Team Salary falls below the applicable Apron Restriction.

The **Salary Limit** is how much **Incoming Trade Salary (ITS)** is permitted, which always depends on the Team‚Äôs **Outgoing Trade Salary (OTS)**, other than the Room TPE. Visit the [Trade Salary](https://cbaguide.com/transactions/trades/tradesalary/) page to review how Trade Salary is calculated.

### Aggregated TPE

| Apron Restriction | Second Apron          |
| ----------------- | --------------------- |
| Outgoing Players  | 2+\*                  |
| Incoming Players  | 1+                    |
| Simultaneous      | Simultaneous          |
| Salary Limit      | 100% Outgoing + $250k |

### Expanded TPE

| Apron Restriction                                                                                                                                                 | First Apron  |
| ----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- | ------------ |
| Outgoing Players                                                                                                                                                  | 1+           |
| Incoming Players                                                                                                                                                  | 1+           |
| Simultaneous                                                                                                                                                      | Simultaneous |
| **Salary Limit** Outgoing Salary Incoming Salary Less than $7.25MM 200% Outgoing + $250k $7.25MM ‚Äì $29MM 100% Outgoing + $8,527,000 More than $29MM 125% Outgoing |              |

### Standard TPE

| Apron Restriction | First Apron(time limitation only)\*\* |
| ----------------- | ------------------------------------- |
| Outgoing Players  | 1                                     |
| Incoming Players  | 1+                                    |
| Simultaneous      | Non-Simultaneous                      |
| Salary Limit      | 100% Outgoing + $250k                 |

### Room TPE

| Apron Restriction | Salary Cap                |
| ----------------- | ------------------------- |
| Outgoing Players  | 1+                        |
| Incoming Players  | 1+                        |
| Simultaneous      | Simultaneous              |
| Salary Limit      | $250k over the Salary Cap |

\* The Aggregated TPE doesn‚Äôt require 2 or more outgoing players, but the Standard TPE would be used if only 1 Player was outgoing, as the same incoming Trade Salary is permitted for both.

\*\* The First Apron only limits the length of time a Standard TPE can be used (discussed below).

title: The ‚ÄúTraded Player Exception‚Äù Term Confusion
content:
The term **Traded Player Exception** or a **TPE** is used by the media and the public differently than how it is used in the CBA.

In the CBA, the Traded Player Exception is the broad term referring to either the Aggregated, Expanded, Standard or Room TPE‚Äôs.

In the media, when they say a Team has a TPE, they are referring to the remaining money in Standard TPE that can be used to acquire another player without sending out additional Salary (this is discussed below).

Just know that when the media says something like ‚Äúthe Knicks have a $15 million TPE‚Äù they mean that the Knicks made a prior trade using the Standard TPE, which hasn‚Äôt expired yet. But in the CBA, a Traded Player Exception can refer to all of the different types of TPE‚Äôs.

title: Look Through the Lense of Each Team Separately
content:
When determining if/how a Trade can work, you look through the lense of each Team separately, and optimize the Exceptions for each Team as best you can.

Not only do you look at each Team separately, but the Trade can be broken apart into multiple trades, so long as each separate Trade satisfies [Trade Salary](https://cbaguide.com/transactions/trades/tradesalary/) and the TPE‚Äôs.

**üèÄ** **Bridges Trade Broken Into Five Separate Trades for Nets**  
One of the best examples of this was the Mikal Bridges trade to the Knicks. From the Knicks point-of-view, they gathered up all of the Outgoing Salary they could to make one trade using the Aggregated TPE. The Nets on the other hand, executed FIVE separate trades, to absorb salaries using different exceptions to generate separate Standard TPE‚Äôs that could be used in the future.  
  
Review an article detailing this trade [here](https://notradeclause.com/trade-mechanics-breaking-down-the-mikal-bridges-trade-to-the-knicks/).

title: Apron Salary vs. Trade Salary
content:
Note the difference between [Apron Team Salary ](https://cbaguide.com/thresholds/apron/)and [Trade Salary](https://cbaguide.com/transactions/trades/tradesalary/).

Trade Salary is used to determine if the Salary Limits for the applicable TPE is satisfied. Apron Team Salary is used to determine if a Team falls below the First or Second Apron, which then determines if certain TPE‚Äôs are available.

These calculations can be different.

**üèÄ** **Jovic‚Äôs ITS Different Than His Apron Salary**  
In the 2025 offseason, Nikola Jovic signed a 4-year, $62.4 million Rookie Scale Extension with the Heat. The extended term begins in 2026-27\. If he is traded prior to the 2026-27 Year, then he is ‚Äúpoison pilled‚Äù and his ITS is the average annual value of his Contract: $13,369,083\. However, his Apron Salary is only $4,445,417.

title: Summarizing the TPE‚Äôs
content:
Before diving into the details of the TPE, it‚Äôs beneficial to see generally (i) what is limited when exceeding each Threshold and (ii) what is never limited in Trade.

**Limitations When Exceeding Threshold:**

| Threshold Exceeded | Limitation                                                                                         |
| ------------------ | -------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- |
| Salary Cap         | TPE required to execute Trade                                                                      |
| First Apron        | Can receive more Incoming Trade Salary than Outgoing Trade Salary                                  |
| Second Apron       | Cannot combine (‚Äúaggregate‚Äù) contracts in a single Trade to satisfy required Outgoing Trade Salary |

**What is Never Restricted in Trade:**

More OTS and ITS ‚Äì Sending out more OTS than ITS will never, on its own, be a reason a Team cannot execute a Trade.

Receiving more Players than Sending Out ‚Äì No TPE restricts a Team‚Äôs ability to acquire more Players than sending out (Roster requirements still must be met).

**üèÄ** **The Suns as a Second Apron Team**  
During the 2025 Offseason, the Suns were seeking to trade Kevin Durant‚Äôs $54.7 million Salary, and were a Second Apron Team. What they can do is acquire two $27 million Salaries for his outgoing salary. What they could not do, is aggregate Royce O‚ÄôNeal‚Äôs $9.3 million and Cody Martin‚Äôs $8.1 million Contracts for one $15 million Contract, even though they are sending out more than they are receiving.

title: Standard TPE
content:
### Standard TPE

| Apron Restriction | First Apron(for time limitation only) |
| ----------------- | ------------------------------------- |
| Outgoing Players  | 1                                     |
| Incoming Players  | 1+                                    |
| Simultaneous      | Non-Simultaneous                      |
| Salary Limit      | 100% Outgoing + $250k                 |

### General Use

The Standard TPE is always going to be the TPE used when (i) there is one outgoing Player and (ii) the outgoing Player‚Äôs Trade Salary is more than the Incoming Trade Salary.

This is because there is no need for the Expanded TPE (don‚Äôt need to acquire more money than sending out) or the Aggregated TPE (don‚Äôt need to send out more than one Player).

### Non-Simultaneous Trade

The major benefit to the Standard TPE is that it is **non-simultaenous**, which is not the case for any other TPE. The Team has 12 months ([or less if over the First Apron](#caveat)) to complete the Trade.

**‚úçÔ∏è** The technical sense of the Non-Simultaenous Trade is this: The Trade is not completed until all of the money in the TPE runs out, or the time runs out to use the TPE. So for the Team, it is all considered one, ongoing non-simultaneous trade.

What this means: The Team trades Player A for X amount of dollars more than the Incoming Trade Salary acquired. They now have a TPE for X dollars plus $250k. The Team has 12 months ([or less if over the First Apron](#caveat)) to acquire additional players using this TPE without the need to send out more Outgoing Salary.

**üèÄ** **Celtics Acquire Large TPE for Hayward**  
In 2020, the Celtics were able to obtain the largest TPE in history by sending Hayward via Sign-and-Trade to the Hornets. Because the Hornets were below the Salary Cap, they could have signed him outright. However, in the trade they absorbed his salary without any outgoing salary back to Boston in exchange for additional draft capital. A $28.5 million TPE was generated, allowing Boston to acquire Evan Fournier four months later. Similarly, Fournier was traded from the Celtics to the Knicks in a Sign-and-Trade creating yet another TPE, which was then used to acquire Derrick White.

### The Time-Crunch Caveat

There is no Apron limitation to use the Standard TPE, generally. But if you are over the First Apron, your 12-month time limitation to use the TPE shortens to the following:

If the Standard TPE arose _during_ the Regular Season, then it expires at the conclusion of the current Regular Season.

If the Standard TPE arose _after_ the Regular Season and before the following Regular Season starts, then it expires after the day of that following Regular Season.

title: Aggregated TPE
content:
### Aggregated TPE

| Apron Restriction | Second Apron          |
| ----------------- | --------------------- |
| Outgoing Players  | 2+\*                  |
| Incoming Players  | 1+                    |
| Simultaneous      | Simultaneous          |
| Salary Limit      | 100% Outgoing + $250k |

 \* The Aggregated TPE doesn‚Äôt require 2 or more outgoing players, but the Standard TPE would be used if only 1 Player was outgoing, as the same incoming Trade Salary is permitted for both.

### General Use

The Aggregated TPE is used to combine multiple players to add up to enough Outgoing Trade Salary to acquire a Player with a larger amount of Incoming Trade Salary.

It is limited in the sense that you can only acquire 100% Outgoing Salary + $250k of what you are sending out. If you are looking to acquire more Trade Salary than you are sending out, then you must use the Expanded TPE, which is only available to Teams below the First Apron.

**üèÄ** **Magic Aggregate Players to Acquire Bane**  
The Magic used the Aggregated TPE to aggregate the Trade Salary of Kentavious Caldwell-Pope and Cole Anthony to create enough Outgoing Trade Salary to absorb the Incoming Trade Salary of Desmond Dane.

Note the Aggregated TPE is restricted to Teams below the Second Apron. So even if a Second Apron Team wants to aggregate players in one trade to obtain one player making _less_ money, they can‚Äôt do so.

**üèÄ** **A Second Apron Hypothetical**  
A Second Apron Team wants to trade Player A ($9.3 million) and Player B ($10.1 million), totaling $19.4 million, for one Player making $17 million to help cut costs. They can‚Äôt do so if they still are over the Second Apron after the Trade, because they are a Second Apron team restricted from aggregating Players in trade. Note, if it cuts enough Salary to drop the Team below the Second Apron, then they could use the Aggregated TPE, as it only matters where the Team lands _after_ the trade.

title: Expanded TPE
content:
### Expanded TPE

| Apron Restriction                                                                                                                                                 | First Apron  |
| ----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- | ------------ |
| Outgoing Players                                                                                                                                                  | 1+           |
| Incoming Players                                                                                                                                                  | 1+           |
| Simultaneous                                                                                                                                                      | Simultaneous |
| **Salary Limit** Outgoing Salary Incoming Salary Less than $7.25MM 200% Outgoing + $250k $7.25MM ‚Äì $29MM 100% Outgoing + $8,527,000 More than $29MM 125% Outgoing |              |

The Expanded TPE is the most flexible of the TPE‚Äôs, which is why it is only available to Teams below the First Apron. 

It is the only TPE that allows more Incoming Trade Salary than Outgoing Trade Salary, and allows for more than one Player to be aggregated in Outgoing Trade Salary.

The amount of ITS allowed is dependant on the amount of OTS (see chart above). Note that the $8,527,000 cushion is increased in in line with the Salary Cap each season.

**üèÄ** **Thunder Use Expanded TPE in Caruso Trade**  
In 2024, the Thunder traded Josh Giddey‚Äôs $6.5 million Contract for Caruso‚Äôs $9.4 million using the Expanded TPE.

title: Room TPE
content:
### Room TPE

| Apron Restriction | Salary Cap                |
| ----------------- | ------------------------- |
| Outgoing Players  | 1+                        |
| Incoming Players  | 1+                        |
| Simultaneous      | Simultaneous              |
| Salary Limit      | $250k over the Salary Cap |

The Room TPE simply allows Teams that are landing slightly over the Salary Cap a $250k buffer to execute the trade.

The Room TPE cannot be used simultaneously with another TPE.

A Team is able to use a the Expanded TPE other than the Room TPE if it chooses, even if the Team has enough Cap Space to execute the Trade using the Room TPE.

title: The $250k Cushion and the First Apron
content: Any time there is a $250k cushion referenced, that cushion is eliminated if the Team lands over the First Apron.

title: Future Aggregation of Acquired Player
content:
If a Player was acquired using a Salary Cap Exception, then such Player cannot be **aggregated** in a subsequent trade for two months from the date of acquisition.

* Exception ‚Äì Prohibition does not apply if (i) Player was acquired prior to December 17th and (ii) is subsequently traded on the Trade Deadline or the day before the Trade Deadline of the same Salary Cap Year.

**üèÄ** **Schr√∂der reaggregated in Trade using Timeline Exception**  
In 2024, Dennis Schr√∂der was traded from the Nets to the Warriors on December 15th using the Standard TPE. Because he was traded prior to December 17th, he could be aggregated in a trade on the Trade Deadline or the day prior to the Trade Deadline. He was then used in the trade for Jimmy Butler.

title: The ‚ÄúStacking Minimum Contracts‚Äù Limitation
content:
The CBA limits the ability for Teams to combine several [Minimum Contracts](https://cbaguide.com/contractanatomy/terms/contractlimitations/) to reach the applicable Outgoing Trade Salary needed to execute a Trade. Below is the specific rule.

A Team cannot trade more than one **Minimum Traded Player** if the following elements are met:

1. Trade takes place _outside of_ December 15th through the NBA Deadline;
2. The Team is aggregating 3+ Contracts in Outgoing Salary;
3. The number of incoming Players is less than the number of outgoing Players

**Minimum Traded Player**

Defined as a Player whose Contract provides for his applicable [Minimum Salary](https://cbaguide.com/contractanatomy/terms/contractlimitations/) for the current Season in which the trade occurs, _unless_ the trade is after the Regular Season, at which point it is the Salary for the subsequent Salary Cap Year.

title: Disabled Player Exception Limitation
content: If a Team acquired a Player using the [DPE](https://cbaguide.com/thresholds/salarycap/#dpe), then they cannot use him as part of a Traded Player Exception.

title: Hard Capping at each Threshold
content:
Discussed in more detail in the [Aprons](https://cbaguide.com/thresholds/apron/) page, it‚Äôs important to note that when a Team uses an Exception that has an Apron limitation, the Team is then **hard capped** at that Apron and can‚Äôt go over it for the remainder to Season (and sometimes, the subsequent Season).

This is to prohibit teams from acting like a Team that‚Äôs below the First Apron, use an Exception that‚Äôs below the First Apron, to then just go over the First Apron afterward.

Because of this rule, Teams will make their best effort to avoid the Expanded TPE if possible to avoid the First Apron hard cap, particularly if their Apron Salary is close to the threshold.

**üèÄ** **Knicks Avoid First Apron Hard Cap in Bridges Trade**  
In the Aggregated TPE example above, the Knicks could have simply sent Bojan Bogdonavic ($19,032,850) in exchange for Mikal Bridges ($23,300,000) using the Expanded TPE. Howevever, they wanted to get to the 100% outgoing salary and use the Aggregated TPE so they were not hard capped at the First Apron.

Trades ‚Äì Trade Salary

**Trade Salary** is a term this Guide uses to define how much a Player‚Äôs Salary counts _specifically_ when calculating Salary for a Traded Player Exception. It is different than Salary or Apron Salary, because different adjustments are made, specifically for when a Trade is made.  
  
Salary can be adjusted solely for the Receiving Team, called **Incoming Trade Salary**, for the Sending Team, called **Outgoing Trade Salary**, or for both.

title: What Isn‚Äôt Salary?
content:
There are a few Tradeable Assets and certain Contract Types that count as $0 in Trade Salary:

**Asset Types**

When any of these assets are included in Trade, they don‚Äôt have to be calculated as Incoming or Outgoing Trade Salary:

1. Draft Picks/Swaps;
2. Draft Rights;
3. Cash-in-Trade.

**Contract Types**

1. [Two-Way Contracts](https://cbaguide.com/contractanatomy/contracttypes/#twoway);
2. Minimium Exception Contracts ‚Äì Any Contract that fits into the [Minimum Exception](https://cbaguide.com/thresholds/salarycap/#minimum) counts as $0 in Incoming Trade Salary _only_.

**üí°** **Using Minimum Exception to Advantage**  
Teams often use this rule to their advantage, as the Sending Team can increase their Outgoing Trade Salary by including Minimum Exception Contracts in the Trade, while none of those Contracts count as Incoming Trade Salary for the Receiving Team.  
  
Not that the [Stacking Minimum Contracts](https://cbaguide.com/transactions/trades/tpe/#stacking) rule limits this to an extent.

title: Summary of Adjustments
content:
| Type                             | Incoming/Outgoing Trade Salary Adjustment |
| -------------------------------- | ----------------------------------------- |
| Team-Related Bonuses             | Both. Adjust on a Team-by-Team basis.     |
| Non-Guaranteed Salary            | Outgoing Trade Salary                     |
| Sign-and-Trade Using Bird Rights | Outgoing Trade Salary                     |
| Minimum Exception                | Incoming Trade Salary                     |
| Rookie Scale Extensions          | Incoming Trade Salary                     |
| Trade Bonus                      | Incoming Trade Salary                     |

title: Incentive Compensation Adjustment
content:
A _Team_ Related Performance Bonus is determined Likely or Unlikely based on the Team‚Äôs prior performance. If the Player changes Teams, the Bonus could then shift from Likely to Unlikely, or vice versa. This has to be accounted for in Trade.

When a Player is Traded, apply the likeliness test for each individual Team. 

If it is a Likely Bonus for the Receiving Team, then include it in Incoming Trade Salary, but if it‚Äôs an Unlikely Bonus for the Sending Team, then exclude it for Outgoing Trade Salary (and vice versa).

**üèÄ** **Brooks‚Äô Bonus Likely for Houston, Unlikely for Phoenix**  
In 2025, the Suns traded Kevin Durant to the Rockets for Dillon Brooks and Jalen Green. Durant‚Äôs Salary was $54,708,609\. Green‚Äôs Salary was $33,333,333.  
  
Brooks, on the other hand, had a $1 million Bonus related to reaching the First Round of the Playoffs. The Rockets achieved this the prior year. Therefore, his Salary _for the Rockets_ was $22,124,110.  
  
The Suns did _not_ make the First Round the year prior, so the Bonus would not be triggered, and his Salary _for the Suns_ is reduced to $21,124,110\. This slight reduction is crucial, because the Suns were a Second Apron Team restricted from acquiring more Trade Salary than sending out. See the calculations below.  
  
| Durant ‚Äì $54,708,609 |               |             |
| -------------------- | ------------- | ----------- |
| |  Rockets Outgoing  | Suns Incoming |             |
| Green                | $33,333,333   | $33,333,333 |
| Brooks               | $22,124,110   | $21,124,110 |
| Total                | $55,457,443   | $54,457,443 |

title: Outgoing Trade Salary Adjustments
Non-Guaranteed Salary Reduced
content:
### Calculating the Reduction

When calculating Outgoing Trade Salary you have to reduce the amount of non-guaranteed Salary depending on when the Trade is made during the Salary Cap Year.

| Stage of Season                   | Treatment of Salary                                                                                                                                  |
| --------------------------------- | ---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- |
| 7/1 until the Regular Season      | Only include guaranteed Salary.                                                                                                                      |
| Regular Season through 1/7        | Prorate the earned Salary (take the full Salary and multiply by the remaining percentage of the Season remaining).                                   |
| 1/8 to end of Regular Season      | Treat all Salary as fully protected (i.e. no reduction).                                                                                             |
| After Regular Season through 6/30 | Take the lesser of (i) the Player‚Äôs Salary for the current Salary Cap Year and (ii) the Player‚Äôs guaranteed Salary of the following Salary Cap Year. |

### Amending the Guarantee

Teams have the ability to amend [Compensation Protection](https://cbaguide.com/contractanatomy/terms/compensationprotection/) (i.e. guaranteed Salary) throughout the life the Contract. Teams have used this often to execute trades under the new Apron limitations.

**üèÄ** **Caruso‚Äôs Salary Fully Guaranteed to Execute Trade**  
In the 2024 offseason, Alex Caruso was traded from the Bulls to the Thunder. In June his Salary for the current Salary Cap Year was $9.4\. His Salary for 2024-2025 was $9.8, but it was only guaranteed for $3 million. This meant his Outgoing Trade Salary was only $3 million, unless amended. The Bulls amended his contract to be fully guaranteed. Therefore his $9.4 million Salary for the prior Salary Cap Year applied (because it was the lesser of the two) allowing them to trade his $9.4 million Contract in exchange for Giddey‚Äôs $6.5 million Contract. 

.

title: Sign-and-Trade of Bird Rights
content:
The Player‚Äôs Outgoing Trade Salary is adjusted in a Sign-and-Trade if:

1. The Player is traded pursuant to a [Sign-and-Trade](https://cbaguide.com/transactions/trades/signandtrade/);
2. The Sending Team signs him using [Full Bird](https://cbaguide.com/thresholds/salarycap/#bird) or [Early Bird Rights](https://cbaguide.com/thresholds/salarycap/#bird); and
3. The first Season‚Äôs [Salary](https://cbaguide.com/contractanatomy/terms/compensation/salary/) plus [Unlikely Bonuses](https://cbaguide.com/contractanatomy/terms/compensation/incentivecompensation/#performance) is greater than what could be signed using [Non-Bird Rights](https://cbaguide.com/thresholds/salarycap/#bird)

**Adjustment Made to Outgoing Trade Salary**

If the rule applies, then his Outgoing Trade Salary is the _greater_ of:

1. The Salary for the last Season of the Player‚Äôs prior Contract, or
2. 50% of the Salary for the first Season of the new Contract.

**üèÄ** **Strus Sign-and-Trade Subjects Him to Rule**  
In July 2023, Max Strus signed a 4-Year, $62.3 million contract as part of a Sign-and-Trade with the Heat and acquired by the Cavs. His starting Salary was $14,487,684.  
  
Because he signed with the Heat using Full Bird Rights for more than he could have signed for Non-Bird Rights, he was subject to the rule. His Prior Salary was only $1,815,677\. Therefore, 50% of his starting Salary ($7,243,842) was used as his Outgoing Trade Salary for Miami.

**No Minimum Salary Subsidy** **for Prior Contract**

If the prior Contract was for [Minimum Salary](https://cbaguide.com/contractanatomy/terms/contractlimitations/), then _don‚Äôt subsidize_ it in the calculation (i.e. don‚Äôt apply just the 2 [YOS](https://cbaguide.com/definitions/#yos) minimum, but apply the Minimum Salary actually paid to the Player according to his YOS accrued).

title: Minimum Exception
content:
As discussed briefly above, a Contract falling within the scope of the [Minimum Exception](https://cbaguide.com/thresholds/salarycap/#minimum) can be acquired via Trade and will count as $0 Incoming Trade Salary. The Contract will count as Outgoing Trade Salary for the Sending Team.

Note this is why the CBA limits the [‚Äústacking‚Äù of Minimum Contracts](https://cbaguide.com/trades/tpe/#stacking), when Teams seek to add up several Minimum Contracts to reach the required Outgoing Trade Salary, knowing it counts as $0 in Incoming Trade Salary for the Receiving Team.

title: Rookie Scale Extensions (the ‚ÄúPoison Pill‚Äù Provision)
content:
### General Rule

The CBA applies a **Poison Pill Provision** for Players who have signed a [Rookie Scale Extension](https://cbaguide.com/transactions/extensions/) based on the understanding the Player‚Äôs value is much higher than his cost-controlled Salary in the 4th Season of his [Rookie Scale Contract](https://cbaguide.com/transactions/signings/draftpicks/).

The Poison Pill is triggered if:

1. A Rookie Scale Extension is signed; and
2. The Player is Traded before the Extension begins.

### Incoming Trade Salary

When the Poison Pill is triggered, his Incoming Trade Salary is his Average Annual Salary of his entire Contract, including Option Year.

### If Based on Percentage

If the [Rookie Extension](https://cbaguide.com/transactions/extensions/) is based on a Percentage (e.g. 25% of the Salary Cap), then assume the Salary Cap increases 104.5% for the first year of the extended term, and assume he does not reach any [Higher Max Criteria](https://cbaguide.com/contractanatomy/terms/contractlimitations/#criteria) benchmarks.

If such calculation exceeds the Player‚Äôs [Maximum Salary](https://cbaguide.com/contractanatomy/terms/contractlimitations/), reduce it to his Maximum Salary.

title: Trade Bonuses
content:
Despite the Sending Team paying the [Trade Bonus](https://cbaguide.com/transactions/trades/tradebonus/), the Receiving Team accounts the Trade Bonus as Incoming Trade Salary (it is also added as [Team Salary](https://cbaguide.com/thresholds/teamsalary/) for the Receiving Team).

When determining Incoming Trade Salary for Trade Math purposes, you use the portion of the [Trade Bonus](https://cbaguide.com/transactions/trades/tradebonus/#calculation) that is allocated to the current Salary Cap Year of the Trade.

Visit the [Trade Bonus](https://cbaguide.com/transactions/trades/tradebonus/) page for a detailed explanation for calculating the Trade Bonus both in the current Salary Cap Year (relevant for Trade Salary) and over the length of the Contract.

### Trade Bonus Calculator

Use the [Trade Bonus Calculator ](https://cbaguide.com/tools/tbcalculator/)to find the Trade Bonus Amount for all current Player‚Äôs currently with Trade Bonuses. You can adjust the trade date to see how the amount changes, including yearly allocation.

Trade Bonus

 A **Trade Bonus** or ‚ÄúTrade Kicker‚Äù is permitted in all Contracts, allowing a Player to receive a one-time Bonus during the life of the Contract should he be traded. The amount of the Trade Bonus can be a fixed amount or based on a percentage of Base Compensation remaining to be earned, but the CBA places an overall limit of 15% of Base Compensation. Calculating the amount of a Trade Bonus can be difficult when based on a percentage because it adjusts throughout the life of the Contract.

title: Amount
content:
Trade Bonuses are limited to 15% of the Player‚Äôs [Base Compensation](https://cbaguide.com/contractanatomy/terms/compensation/basecompensation/).

The Trade Bonus can be a percentage of [Base Compensation](https://cbaguide.com/contractanatomy/terms/compensation/basecompensation/) or a fixed amount (not to exceed the maximum 15% Base Compensation).

Contracts can also condition the amount as the lesser of the two (e.g. the lesser of 5% [Base Compensation](https://cbaguide.com/contractanatomy/terms/compensation/basecompensation/) to be earned or $5 million).

title: Trade Bonus Paid Once
content:
A Trade Bonus is only paid once. If the Contract is traded a second time, there is no more Trade Bonus to be paid.

**‚úçÔ∏è** **No Trade Clause Stays, while Trade Bonuses Extinguish**  
While a Trade Bonus is only paid one time, a No Trade Clause stays for the length of the Contract. This happened, for example, when Bradley Beal waived his No Trade Clause to be traded to the Suns, but would not waive it to be dealt elsewhere.

If the Trade Bonus is part of a [Sign-and-Trade](https://cbaguide.com/transactions/trades/signandtrade/) or [Extend-and-Trade](https://cbaguide.com/transactions/trades/signandtrade/#extend), then the Trade Bonus isn‚Äôt triggered when the Contract is first signed and the Player is immediately traded. Instead, the Trade Bonus would be triggered on a subsequent trade.

While the Trade Bonus is added to the Receiving Team‚Äôs [Team Salary](https://cbaguide.com/thresholds/teamsalary/) (calculated below), the Sending Team pays the Trade Bonus.

title: Amending as Part of Trade
content:
The Player can agree to reduce all or a portion of the Trade Bonus _as part of a Trade_ (this is different than amending the Trade Bonus before a Trade occurs, discussed below).

This occurs when a Player wishes to be traded to a more desirable Team and the waiver of the Trade Bonus allows the Trade Salary to work for the execution of the Trade.

The Player‚Äôs Contract cannot be [renegotiated](https://cbaguide.com/transactions/renegotiations/) for six months from the date of the Trade if he reduces his Trade Bonus.

title: Amending Prior to Trade
content:
Prior to a Trade, a Trade Bonus can only be adjusted, removed or added as part of an [Extension](https://cbaguide.com/transactions/extensions/) (and in some circumstances, an [Extend-and-Trade](https://cbaguide.com/transactions/trades/signandtrade/#extend)).

Different rules apply if (i) adjusting the amount of the Trade Bonus, (ii) adding a new Trade Bonus or (iii) removing an existing Trade Bonus.

**Adjusting the Amount of Trade Bonus** 

A Trade Bonus amount can be adjusted _for the extended term_ of the Contract when an [Extension](https://cbaguide.com/transactions/extensions/) is signed. 

As part of an [Extend-and-Trade](https://cbaguide.com/transactions/trades/signandtrade/#extend), the Trade Bonus can only be _reduced_.

**Adding a Trade Bonus** 

A Trade Bonus can be added to a Contract that did not have one when an [Extension](https://cbaguide.com/transactions/extensions/) is signed (payable after the signing of the Extension) or [Extend-and-Trade](https://cbaguide.com/transactions/trades/signandtrade/#extend) (payable in trade subsequent to the initial trade).

The Trade Bonus is due if the trade occurs any time after the signing of the [Extension](https://cbaguide.com/transactions/extensions/), or any trade subsequent to the initial trade if it was part of an [Extend-and-Trade](https://cbaguide.com/transactions/trades/signandtrade/#extend).

**Removing a Trade Bonus**

A Trade Bonus can be removed from the extended term of the Contract when signing an [Extension](https://cbaguide.com/transactions/extensions/) or [Extend-and-Trade](https://cbaguide.com/transactions/trades/signandtrade/#extend).

If traded during the original term, the Trade Bonus is due, and is calculated based on remaining [Base Compensation](https://cbaguide.com/contractanatomy/terms/compensation/basecompensation/) owed in original term of Contract (the Player can still waive the Trade Bonus in connection with the Trade as discussed above).

If traded during the extended term, then no Trade Bonus is due.

title: Trade Bonus Allocation
content:
Allocating the Trade Bonus as Salary is similar to a [Signing Bonus](https://cbaguide.com/contractanatomy/terms/paymentarrangements/#signingbonus) because it is defined as a Signing Bonus in the CBA.

Therefore, a Trade Bonus is allocated across the guaranteed Seasons remaining in the contract.

However, a Trade Bonus is different than a Signing Bonus because (i) the amount is based upon remaining Base Compensation owed, and (ii) a Trade Bonus will inevitably be triggered partway through the Contract. As a result, the Trade Bonus amount adjusts throughout the life of the Contract.

Below is a Roadmap for calculating Trade Bonus amounts, followed by the step-by-step instructions.

title: Trade Bonus Math ‚Äì The Roadmap
Step 1 ‚Äì Total Trade Bonus Amount
content:
Before you can allocate the Trade Bonus as Salary per Season, you must first determine the _total_ amount of the Trade Bonus‚Äìi.e. the ‚ÄúTotal Trade Bonus Amount.‚Äù

If it is a Fixed Trade Bonus Amount, then you already know the Total Trade Bonus Amount. You can move on to ‚Äú[Step 2 ‚Äì Allocate Total Trade Bonus Amount](#allocate)‚Äù below.

If it is a Percentage-Based Trade Bonus, you need to follow the below steps to find the Total Trade Bonus Amount:

### Total Base Compensation Owed (TBCO)

When based on a percentage, you must calculate the total guaranteed [Base Compensation](https://cbaguide.com/contractanatomy/terms/compensation/basecompensation/) _remaining to be owed_ to the Player _as of the date of the trade_, excluding Option years (the **Total Base Compensation Owed**).

Once the Total Base Compensation Owed is found, you take the percentage from that to find the Total Trade Bonus Amount.

Because you find the Total Base Compensation Owed as of the date of the trade, the Current Season Base Compensation Owed changes on a daily basis throughout the Regular Season. 

Therefore, you must first determine the **Current Season Base Compensation Owed** as of the date of the trade, using the steps below:

### Current Season Base Compensation Owed

The Current Season Base Compensation Owed can be tricky, as it adjusts on a daily basis once the Regular Season begins.

Therefore, to determine the Current Season Base Compensation owed, you must first find the **Percent Regular Season Remaining**:

**Regular Season Percentage ‚Äì Before or After the Regular Season**:

1. If the Trade occurs before the start of the Regular Season, then 100% of the Regular Season remains. Factor the entire guaranteed [Base Compensation](https://cbaguide.com/contractanatomy/terms/compensation/basecompensation/) for the current Season as part of the calculation.
2. If the Trade occurs _after_ the Regular Season concludes, but before the new Salary Cap Year. Then 0% of the Regular Season remains. Exclude the current Season‚Äôs Salary from the Trade Bonus Calculation, because it is not ‚Äúremaining to be owed.‚Äù

**‚úçÔ∏è** Note that you still include the current Season as part of the yearly allocation if the trade occurred prior to July 1st (i.e. the start of the new Salary Cap Year). More on this below. 

**Regular Season Percentage ‚Äì During the Regular Season**:

If the Trade occurs during the Regular Season:

1. Find the number of days that have elapsed from the start of the Regular Season (174 in 2025-26 ) to the date of the Trade. These are your **Days Elapsed**.
2. Subtract Days Elapsed from Regular Season Days to find **Days Remaining**.
3. Divide your Days Remaining by the total number of Regular Season Days in the Salary Cap Year. This is your **Percentage Elapsed**.
4. Multiply the Player‚Äôs guaranteed [Base Compensation](https://cbaguide.com/contractanatomy/terms/compensation/basecompensation/) by this Percentage Elapsed to find the remaining amount owed for the current season to find the Current Season Based Compensation Owed.

### Total Base Compensation Owed ‚Äì All Seasons

Next, add the Current Season Base Compensation Owed to the all guaranteed Base Compensation remaining over future Seasons, _excluding Option Years_.

This is the Player‚Äôs **Total Base Compensation Owed** (**TBCO**).

### Multiply TBCO by the Percentage

Multiply the Total Base Compensation Owed by the applicable percentage to find the Player‚Äôs **Total Trade Bonus Amount**.

If the Player had a ‚Äúlesser of‚Äù condition between the percentage and a fixed amount, now you can determine whether the fixed amount is less than the percentage. Apply the proper Total Trade Bonus Amount.

This amount may be adjusted down if the yearly allocation exceeds the Maximum Salary. But we don‚Äôt know that until after the allocation is completed, and then we adjust. So let‚Äôs move on to our next step.

title: Step 2 ‚Äì Allocate Total Trade Bonus Amount
content:
### Allocate Using Pro Rata Math

Once the Total Trade Bonus is found using the steps above, you allocate the Total Trade Bonus over the total number of guaranteed Seasons remaining on the Contract. Use the same calculation as the ‚Äú[Signing Bonus Math](https://cbaguide.com/contractanatomy/terms/compensation/salary/#signingbonuses)‚Äù in the Salary page.

Note that if the trade occurs after the Regular Season, but before July 1st (i.e. the new Salary Cap Year), you allocate Salary to the current Season even though there is $0 remaining to be owed for the current Season.

**üèÄ** **Examples of Season Allocations**

Example 1 ‚Äì Player has a 4-Year, $100 million contract at $25 million per year starting in 2025-2026 going through 2028-2029\. He‚Äôs traded in June 2026\. He has $75 million remaining to be earned, allocated over 4 seasons.  
  
Example 2 ‚Äì With the same Contract, Player is traded in July 2026\. He has $75 million remaining to be earned, but allocated over 3 seasons because it is the start of a new Salary Cap Year so 2025-2026 is no longer included.  
  
Example 3 ‚Äì With the same contract, Player is traded exactly halfway through the 2026-2027 Season. He has $62.5 million remaining to be earned ($12.5 million for the 50% remaining in 2026-2027 and $25 million in each of the final 2 seasons), allocated over 3 seasons.

title: Step 3 ‚Äì Maximum Salary Adjustment
content:
One final adjustment required is determining if the Trade Bonus in the current season exceeds the Player‚Äôs applicable [Maximum Salary](https://cbaguide.com/contractanatomy/terms/contractlimitations/). If so, the Trade Bonus for such season must be reduced to the Player‚Äôs Maximum Salary.

Note that Maximum Salary would include a [Rookie Scale Contract](https://cbaguide.com/transactions/signings/draftpicks/) exceeding 120% Salary/Unlikely Bonus.

If the Trade Bonus is deducted for the current Season‚Äôs Salary, then the Trade Bonus allocations for future seasons must also be reduced by the same percentage.

**Step 1 ‚Äì Does Current Season Salary exceed Maximum Salary?**

1. Once the Yearly Allocation is calculated above, you find the Trade Bonus Amount for the current Season (**Current Season Trade Bonus**) and add it to the Player‚Äôs Salary _plus [Unlikely Bonuses](https://cbaguide.com/contractanatomy/terms/compensation/incentivecompensation/#performance)_.
2. If the Player‚Äôs Salary + Unlikely Bonuses + Current Season Trade Bonus does not exceed the Player‚Äôs applicable [Maximum Salary](https://cbaguide.com/contractanatomy/terms/contractlimitations/), then no further adjustment is required.
3. If the Player‚Äôs Salary + Unlikely Bonuses + Current Season Trade Bonus _does_  exceed his Maximum Salary, then make the following adjustment:

**Step 2 ‚Äì Adjust down to Maximum Salary if needed.**

1. Find the Excess: Subtract the applicable [Maximum Salary](https://cbaguide.com/contractanatomy/terms/contractlimitations/) from the Player‚Äôs Salary + Unlikely Bonuses + Current Season Trade Bonus to find the **Excess Trade Bonus Amount**.
2. Find the Allowable Amount: Subtract the Excess Trade Bonus Amount from the Current Season Trade Bonus to find the **Allowable Current Season Trade Bonus Amount**. This is the amount permitted to be added without exceeding the Player‚Äôs Maximum Salary.
3. Find the Percentage Reduction: Take the new Current Season Trade Bonus and divide by the Prior Current Season Trade Bonus to find the **Percentage Reduction**.
4. Apply Percentage Reduction to Future Allocations: Multiply all future seasons allocated Trade Bonus Amounts by the Percentage Reduction to reduce all future seasons in proportion to the Current Season Trade Bonus.

**üèÄ** **Mitchell Trade Bonus Adjusted to Max Salary**  
When Donovan Mitchell was traded right before the start of the 2022-2023 Season from Utah to Cleveland, he was only entering Year 2 of his Designated Rookie Scale Extension containing a 15% percent Trade Bonus. When traded, Mitchell would have earned a $14.6 million Total Trade Bonus had it not been for the Maximum Salary adjustment, which lowered the total Trade Bonus to just $1,685,910 because he was already earning so close to the 25% Maximum Salary before the Trade in the 2022-2023 Season.

title: Trade Bonus and Trade Salary
content:
The Current Season Trade Bonus Amount will count as [Incoming Trade Salary](https://cbaguide.com/transactions/trades/tradesalary/) for the Receiving Team in a Trade, but not as Outgoing Trade Salary for the Sending Team.

Sign-and-Trade

title: Sign-and-Trade
content:
A **Sign-and-Trade** is a mechanism where a Player that is no longer under Contract with his Prior Team, initially signs with his Prior Team on the condition of being traded to a new Team. 

Sign-and-Trade allows a Team to sign a Player using the Prior Team‚Äôs [Bird Rights](https://cbaguide.com/thresholds/salarycap/#bird).

title: Requirements
5th Year Eligible Player
content: Player eligible for the [Higher Max Criteria](https://cbaguide.com/contractanatomy/terms/contractlimitations/#criteria) language is still limited to only 25% of the Salary Cap.

title: Signing Bonus
content: Any payment made by the Sending Team shall be treated as [Cash-in-Trade](https://cbaguide.com/transactions/trades/traderules/#cash) to the Receiving Team (and limited to such rules).

title: Physical Exam Contingency
content: A Sign-and-Trade and Extend-and-Trade cannot contain an [Exhibit 6](https://cbaguide.com/contractanatomy/upc/), but can still be conditioned upon the Player passing a physical exam.

title: Generally
content:
Similar to a Sign-and-Trade, a Team may enter into an [Extension ](https://cbaguide.com/transactions/extensions/)with the Player under the condition he is traded subsequent to the amendment to the Contract. 

When signing an Extend-and-Trade, the terms of the Contract are more restrictive than if signing an Extension and staying with his Prior Team (discussed below).

**üèÄ** **Adams Agrees to Extend-and-Trade With Thunder, Sent to Pelicans**  
In 2020-21, Steven Adams agreed to an Extend-and-Trade. He signed a 2-year, $35 million Extension with the Thunder, and as part of the Extension he was traded to the Pelicans.

title: Eligibility
content: In addition to being [Extension](https://cbaguide.com/transactions/extensions/) eligible, an Extend-and-Trade cannot be signed from the last day of the Regular Season in the last Season of the Contract (including Option Year) through June 30th.

title: Compensation
content:
### Salary

The Extend-and-Trade can include [Salary](https://cbaguide.com/contractanatomy/terms/compensation/salary/) that is _greater of_:

1. 120% of the [Regular Salary](https://cbaguide.com/contractanatomy/terms/compensation/regularsalary/) in the last year of the original term of the Contract; or
2. 120% of the [Estimated Average Player Salary](https://cbaguide.com/definitions/) (EAPS) for the Salary Cap Year in which the Extension is signed.  
   * If the first year of the [Extension](https://cbaguide.com/transactions/extensions/) includes [Incentive Compensation](https://cbaguide.com/contractanatomy/terms/compensation/incentivecompensation/), then 120% of the EAPS less the amount of such Incentive Compensation.

### Incentive Compensation

120% of Likely and Unlkely Incentive Compensation, respectively, in the last year of the original term of the Contract.

### Adjustment for Certain Bonuses

When determining the Player‚Äôs maximum allowable Salary in an Extend-and-Trade, you add (i) bonuses for physical/academic achievement, and (ii) bonuses related to promotional appearances to [Regular Salary](https://cbaguide.com/contractanatomy/terms/compensation/regularsalary/), and exclude them from [Incentive Compensation](https://cbaguide.com/contractanatomy/terms/compensation/incentivecompensation/).

### Increase/Decrease Limitations

For each Salary Cap Year following the first year of a Contract signed via and Extend-and-Trade, the [increase/decrease limitation](https://cbaguide.com/contractanatomy/terms/contractlimitations/#increases) shall be 5% instead of 8% like a typical [Veteran Extension](https://cbaguide.com/transactions/extensions/).

### Years

May not cover more than 4 Seasons (including the remaining Seasons in the Original Contract).

title: Other Considerations
content:
### Trade Bonuses

**Adding a Trade Bonus**

If the original Contract did not include a [T](https://cbaguide.com/contractanatomy/terms/paymentarrangements/)[r](https://cbaguide.com/contractanatomy/terms/paymentarrangements/#tradebonus)[ade Bonus](https://cbaguide.com/contractanatomy/terms/paymentarrangements/), the Contract can be amended to include a Trade Bonus that will be triggered on any _subsequent_ trade (i.e. does not trigger on the Extend-and-Trade).

**Amending Trade Bonus**

In connection with an Extend-and-Trade Contract, you can (i) reduce the amount of the Trade Bonus to be paid to the player or (ii) provide the Trade Bonus will not be applicable to the extended term of the Contract.

If traded during the original term, the Trade Bonus is due, and is calculated based on remaining [Base Compensation](https://cbaguide.com/contractanatomy/terms/compensation/basecompensation/) owed in original term of Contract (the Player can still waive the Trade Bonus at the time of the Trade).

### Physical Exam Contingency

A Sign-and-Trade and Extend-and-Trade cannot contain an Exhibit 6, but can still be conditioned upon the Player passing a physical exam.

 The five thresholds‚ÄìSalary Cap, Minimum Team Salary, Luxury Tax and the First and Second Aprons‚Äìare the backbone of roster-building in today‚Äôs NBA. Each threshold is accompanied by its own rules when exceeding the threshold (or failing to exceed the threshold for Minimum Team Salary purposes). The Guide breaks down the rules for each Threshold on individual pages, linked below.

title: Calculating for Thresholds
content:
Each threshold uses different calculations when determining if a Team is above or below the applicable threshold.

The Salary Cap uses [Team Salary](https://cbaguide.com/thresholds/teamsalary/)**.** 

The [Aprons](https://cbaguide.com/thresholds/apron/) then make adjustments to Team Salary (e.g. removing Cap Holds and adding Unlikely Bonuses), which is called **Apron Team Salary**.

[Minimum Team Salary](https://cbaguide.com/thresholds/minimumsalary/) and the [Luxury Tax](https://cbaguide.com/thresholds/luxurytax/) use Salaries that are calculated for purposes of the audit, called [Total Salaries](https://cbaguide.com/definitions/#totalsalaries), which in simple terms, adjusts for money actually paid by the Teams (e.g. Performance Bonuses earned count, while those unearned do not).

Team Salary

title: Generally
content:
Team Salary is the calculation made to determine how much a Team falls above or below the [Salary Cap](https://cbaguide.com/thresholds/salarycap/) threshold.

Team Salary is not just the [Salaries](https://cbaguide.com/contractanatomy/terms/compensation/salary/) of a Team‚Äôs Players, but includes additional items‚Äìprimarily [Cap Holds](#capholds)‚Äìwhile excluding others.

**‚úçÔ∏è** **Team Salary vs. Apron Salary**  
Team Salary is different than [Apron Salary](https://cbaguide.com/thresholds/apron/). However, to calculate Apron Salary you must first calculate Team Salary and then make additional adjustments to find Apron Salary.

title: Team Salary Summary
Players on Roster
content: Include all [Salaries](https://cbaguide.com/contractanatomy/terms/compensation/salary/) of the Players currently on the Team.

title: Guaranteed Salaries
content: If a Player is [waived](https://cbaguide.com/transactions/waivers/), but has [Protected Compensation](https://cbaguide.com/contractanatomy/terms/compensationprotection/), then the [Dead Salary](https://cbaguide.com/transactions/waivers/#deadsalary) will remain on the Team‚Äôs books after waiving the Player. Visit the [Waiver](https://cbaguide.com/transactions/waivers/) page to review how the [Dead Salary](https://cbaguide.com/transactions/waivers/#deadsalary) is calculated, and how a Team can Stretch the Dead Salary over a longer period of time.

title: Non-Guaranteed Salaries
content:
### The Universal Cutdown Date

Any Contract that is terminated for ‚Äúlack of skill‚Äù from January 10th to the end of the Season is entitled to his full [Base Compensation](https://cbaguide.com/contractanatomy/terms/compensation/basecompensation/) for the Season.

Therefore, if a Team seeks to terminate the Contract prior to the [Salary](https://cbaguide.com/contractanatomy/terms/compensation/salary/) being fully guaranteed for the Season, the Team must allow the Player to clear waivers prior to January 10th (i.e. he must be cut on January 8th).

### Waiver Prior to the Universal Cutdown Date

If a Player‚Äôs Salary is non-guaranteed, then the only Salary that remains on the Team‚Äôs books after waiving the Player is his **Per-Day Cap Hit** starting as of the start of the Regular Season.

To calculate Per-Day Cap Hit, you take the Player‚Äôs Salary and divide by 174 (the number of Regular Season Days).

To calculate Salary earned, you mutiply his Per-Day Cap Hit by the number of days on the roster, _after release_ (not as of the waiver claim, which is two days earlier than release).

**üèÄ** **Fernando Waived Prior to Cutdown Date**  
On the cutdown date during the 2024-25 Season, the Raptors waived Bruno Fernando. Fernando was earning a non-guaranteed Salary of $2,425,403.  
  
$2,425,403 √∑ 174 = $13,939.10 Per-Day Cap Hit.  
  
$13,939.10 x 80 (days on Roster) = $1,115,128 in Dead Salary.

Note that if a Player‚Äôs Salary is subsidized to 2 YOS Minimum Salary, you remove the subsidy should the Player get waived during the Season.

**üèÄ** **Dozier‚Äôs Unsubsidized Salary Subject to Cap Hit**  
In 2024-25, Minnesota signed P.J. Dozier to a 1-year Minimum Contract. With 7 YOS, his Compensation was $2,613,120, but his Salary was subsidized to 2 YOS Minimum Salary of $2,087,519.  
  
On December 28, 2024, Minnesota waived Dozier. Therefore, his Per-Day Cap Hit was calculated based on his unsubsidized Compensation: $2,613,120 √∑ 174 = $15,017.93.  
  
$15,017.93 x 70 (days elapsed) = $1,051,255 in Dead Salary.  
  
_Note Dozier had $1 million guaranteed. Had Dozier been waived earlier in the season where the Per-Day Cap Hit calculation was less then $1 million, then the $1 million would remain as Dead Salary._

If a Team does not want to incur a Per-Day Cap Hit, the Player must be waived by 5:00 P.M. two days prior to the first day of the Regular Season.

title: Pending Contracts
content: [Salaries](https://cbaguide.com/contractanatomy/terms/compensation/salary/) that are anticipated to be included in Team Salary based on any agreement that is required to be disclosed to the NBA.

title: Outstanding Offer Sheets
content: The outstanding [Salaries](https://cbaguide.com/contractanatomy/terms/compensation/salary/) called for under all outstanding [Offer Sheets](https://cbaguide.com/transactions/signings/rfa/#offersheet) through the [Restricted Free Agency](https://cbaguide.com/transactions/signings/rfa/) process.

title: Purpose
Free Agent Cap Holds
content:
A Cap Hold is added to Team Salary for any Player finishing the Season on the Team‚Äôs [Roster](https://cbaguide.com/eligibility/rosters/).

Free Agent Cap Holds are based upon the prior Contract Type and **Prior Salary**.

Prior Salary ‚Äì Include last Season‚Äôs [Regular Salary](https://cbaguide.com/contractanatomy/terms/compensation/regularsalary/), [Signing Bonus](https://cbaguide.com/contractanatomy/terms/paymentarrangements/#signingbonus) allocation and his [Incentive Compensation](https://cbaguide.com/contractanatomy/terms/compensation/incentivecompensation/) that was actually earned when the Player finished the Season.

### Free Agent Cap Hold Formulas

Below are the formulas depending on Contract Type. However, a Cap Hold will never be above or below the Player‚Äôs applicable [Maximum or Minimum Salary](https://cbaguide.com/contractanatomy/terms/contractlimitations/). If the formula exceeds Maximum or Minimum Salary, then adjust the Cap Hold to the limit.

| Prior Contract          | Elements                                                                                    | Percent Prior Salary                                                                             |
| ----------------------- | ------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- | ------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------ |
| Rookie Scale Contract   | 1\. Coming off 4th year;and2\. Prior Salary Below [EAPS](https://cbaguide.com/definitions/) | 300%                                                                                             |
| Rookie Scale Contract   | 1\. Coming off 4th year;and2\. Prior Salary Above [EAPS](https://cbaguide.com/definitions/) | 250%                                                                                             |
| Rookie Scale Contract   | Coming off 2nd or 3rd Year                                                                  | Rookie Scale Amount Only                                                                         |
| Restricted Free Agent   | N/A                                                                                         | Greater of: 1\. Applicable UFA Cap Hold; 2\. Qualifying Offer Amount; 3\. ROFR (matching) Amount |
| Minimum Salary Contract | N/A                                                                                         | New Minimum Salary Amount (never above 2-Year Veteran Minimum)                                   |
| Two-Way Contract        | N/A                                                                                         | Minimum Salary for Player with 0 Years of Service                                                |
| UFA(other than above)   | 1\. Full Bird; and2\. Prior Salary Below [EAPS](https://cbaguide.com/definitions/)          | 190%                                                                                             |
| UFA(other than above)   | 1\. Full Bird; and2\. Prior Above [EAPS](https://cbaguide.com/definitions/)                 | 150%                                                                                             |
| UFA(other than above)   | Early Bird                                                                                  | 130%                                                                                             |
| UFA(other than above)   | Non-Bird                                                                                    | 120%                                                                                             |

title: First Round Pick Cap Holds
Open Roster Spot Cap Hold
Salary Cap Exceptions
content:
### Purpose

This Cap Hold is meant to avoid a situation where a Team can double dip and act as a [Cap Space Team](https://cbaguide.com/thresholds/salarycap/), and then act as a Team with a particular [Salary Cap Exception](https://cbaguide.com/thresholds/salarycap/).

**üèÄ** **Hypothetical Explaining the Purpose**  
Team A has $8 million in cap space below the Salary Cap before considering a Salary Cap Exception Cap Hold. If this rule didn‚Äôt apply, the Team could sign one player to an $8 million contract using Cap Space, and then use the Non-Taxpayer Midlevel Exception to sign another player to a $12 million contract. This rule eliminates this cap space manipulation. Since Team A‚Äôs cap space is less then the NTMLE, a Cap Hold is added for the NTMLE amount and the Team is considered over the Salary Cap.

### When Applied

This Cap Hold is applied in the following circumstance:

1. One or more [Salary Cap Exceptions](https://cbaguide.com/thresholds/salarycap/) are available to the Team; and
2. Team Salary is below the [Salary Cap](https://cbaguide.com/thresholds/salarycap/) by less than the Exceptions available.
3. then the amount of the Exception is included in the Team‚Äôs Team Salary until the Exception is actually used or until the Team is no longer entitled to the Exception.

The amount of the Exception is included in the Team‚Äôs Team Salary until the Exception is actually used or until the Team is no longer entitled to the Exception.

**üèÄ** **Hypothetical When Cap Holds Apply**  
Team A is $18 million under the Salary Cap before Salary Cap Exception Cap Holds apply. Team A has the $14.1 million NTMLE and the $5.1 million Bi-Annual Exception available. Therefore, the Team is $1.2 million over the Salary Cap. If they want to sign one Player to an $18 million Contract, the Team can [renounce](https://cbaguide.com/thresholds/teamsalary/#renouncing) their Exceptions and sign the Player using Cap Space.

### Signings/DPE

When an Exception is used to sign a Player, the Player‚Äôs Salary takes the place of the Cap Hold (any unused portion will remain if the rule above still applies). 

Similarly, when a [DPE](https://cbaguide.com/thresholds/salarycap/#dpe) is used to sign or acquire a player, the Player‚Äôs acquired Salary takes the place of the DPE.

title: Assigned Contracts
content: The assigned Team shall include the _entire_ Salary for then-current and future Salary Cap Years for any assigned Contract (via [Trade](https://cbaguide.com/transactions/trades/) or [Waiver](https://cbaguide.com/transactions/waivers/) claim).

title: Minimum Team Salary Adjustment
content:
If a Team falls below the [Minimum Team Salary threshold](https://cbaguide.com/thresholds/), Team Salary will be adjusted throughout the Salary Cap year to equal the [Minimum Team Salary](https://cbaguide.com/thresholds/minimumsalary/) threshold, starting at the beginning of the Regular Season.

Visit the [Minimum Team Salary](https://cbaguide.com/thresholds/minimumsalary/) page for details.

title: Retired Players Under Contract
content: If a Player retires and a Team continues to pay the Player, allocate the Player‚Äôs unearned [Protected Compensation](https://cbaguide.com/contractanatomy/terms/compensationprotection/) for then-current and remaining Salary Cap Years pro rata over then-current and remaining years on a pro rata basis, _irrespective of payment schedule_.

title: Transactions With Retired Players
content: Any value or consideration determined to be considered Team Salary due to a finding that the transaction circumvented the CBA, per the process discussed in detail in the [Circumvention](https://cbaguide.com/governance/circumvention/#retired) page.

title: Grievances
content: When a Grievance is filed, Team Salary will be affected during the pendency of the proceeding and may be adjusted based upon how the Grievance is resolved.

title: Grievance Pending
content:
When a Grievance is initiated seeking payment of Compensation _for current or future Seasons_ that the Team asserts is not owed, 50% of the amount disputed is allocated as Salary to the Salary Cap Year it related to.

When a Grievance is initiated seeking payment of Compensation for _prior Seasons_, there is no adjustment until resolution.

title: Grievance Resolved ‚Äì Single Year
content:
When the Grievance is resolved the 50% that was applied to Team Salary during the pendency of the proceeding is adjusted up or down depending on the award.

The adjustment is first made to the applicable Salary Cap Year the Grievance is related to. However, if the Salary Cap Year has passed, then the adjustment is made to the Year in which the Grievance is resolved.

### Tax Implications

The Team will be subject to additional tax obligations if the tax payment made is less than the amount it should have paid after the Grievance is resolved.

Vice versa, the Team will be entitled to a tax refund if the Team paid more in tax than it should have after the Grievance is resolved.

title: Grievance Resolved ‚Äì Multiple Years
content:
When the Grievance is resolved and concerns more than one Season, the aggregate amounts payable shall be allocated to each Season in proportion to the amount of Compensation that was in dispute for such Season.

* Exception ‚Äì If the Grievance Arbitrator allocates amounts payable to the Player in specific Seasons in the Grievance Award.

title: Team Salary ‚Äì What‚Äôs Excluded
Renouncing Cap Holds
content:
### Generally

A Team can **renounce** [Cap Holds](#capholds) listed above to remove them from Team Salary.

For Free Agent Cap Holds, the Team provides a written statement to the League renouncing the Team‚Äôs right to resign the Player effective no earlier than July 1st following the last Season covered by the Contract.

### Restricted Free Agent

A Team cannot renounce a Player who is a [Restricted Free Agent](https://cbaguide.com/transactions/signings/rfa/).

A  Team must relinquish ROFR rights to the Player, turning the Player into a [UFA](https://cbaguide.com/transactions/signings/ufa/), which automatically renounces any Free Agent Cap Hold for the Prior Team.

### Effect on Bird Rights

If a Team renounces a Veteran Free Agent Cap Hold, the Team will lose any [Bird Rights](https://cbaguide.com/thresholds/salarycap/#bird) to the Player. The Team will be just like any other Team in free agency at that time and need to use cap space or a different [Exception](https://cbaguide.com/thresholds/salarycap/) to sign the Player.

**‚úçÔ∏è** **Re-signing After Renouncing Does not Reset ‚ÄúBird Clock‚Äù**  
Even if Bird Rights are renounced, the Team can still re-sign the Player and continue to accrue ongoing Bird Rights to the Player.

### Renouncing Down

A Team can ‚Äúrenounce down‚Äù from Early Bird Rights to Non-Bird Rights to avoid the required 2-Year minimum length requirement.

### Offer Sheets and ‚ÄúUnrenouncing‚Äù

A Team won‚Äôt lose [Bird Rights](https://cbaguide.com/thresholds/salarycap/#bird) or [Draft Rights](https://cbaguide.com/eligibility/draftrules/) (if First Round Pick Cap Hold and Draft Rights are renounced) in the following circumstance:

1. Team renounced the Cap Hold to make enough room to sign a different Player to an [Offer Sheet](https://cbaguide.com/transactions/signings/rfa/#offersheet);
2. The Prior Team matched the Offer Sheet and therefore does not sign with the Team;
3. The Team **unrenounces** the Cap Hold within two days of the match (or the physical, if applicable); and
4. The renounced Cap Hold is added back to Team Salary:  
   * It can‚Äôt be added back to Team Salary (and thus the Team still loses Bird rights) if:  
         * Team was at or below the Salary Cap when renouncing, and unrenouncing puts them above the Salary Cap;  
         * Team was above the Salary Cap when renouncing, and unrenouncing would exceed the Team‚Äôs Team Salary at the time of renouncing.

title: Long-Term Injury Exclusion
Contract Types Excluded from Team Salary
The ‚ÄúSoft Cap‚Äù Explained
content:
Each Season, the Salary Cap is a threshold based upon Basketball Related Income (BRI) from the prior Season. To review the details of how it is set, visit the [Finances ](https://cbaguide.com/finances/)section of the Guide, here.

[Team](https://cbaguide.com/thresholds/teamsalary/)[ Salary](https://cbaguide.com/thresholds/teamsalary/) is used to determine if a Team is above or below the Salary Cap. Teams may not exceed the Salary Cap, _unless_ the Team uses an Exception (discussed below) to do so.

This is called a ‚ÄúSoft Cap‚Äù system because while there is a Salary Cap, Teams are permitted to exceed the Salary Cap, and the majority of Teams do so on a year-to-year basis.

title: Availability of Exceptions
content:
To trigger an Exception, a Team must have Team Salary either (i) at/above the Salary Cap or (ii) under the Salary Cap for less then the Exceptions.

**üèÄ** **Examples Triggering and Losing Exceptions**  
Example 1 ‚Äì Exception Larger than Cap Room  
If, for example, the Team has Cap Space of $10 million, and the NTMLE is $14 million, then $14 million is added to Team Salary, putting the Team above the Salary Cap and triggering the availabilty of the Exception.  
  
Example 2 ‚Äì Exception Less than Cap Room  
If, on the other hand, Cap Space is $15 million and the NTMLE is $14 million, then the team must use Cap Room to sign the Player and the NTMLE is not available.  
  
Example 3 ‚Äì Two Exceptions Exceed Cap Room  
If Cap Space is $15 million, but the Team has both the NTMLE of $14 million and the BAE of $4.9 million, then both are added to Team Salary and the Team is above the Salary Cap allowing both Exceptions to be available to the Team.  
  
Example 4 ‚Äì Two Exceptions Available, but Want to Sign One Player  
What if the Exceptions in Example 3 are available, but the Team wants to sign one Player to a $15 million Contract? Since the Exceptions can‚Äôt be aggregated, the Team can renounce the Exceptions, clearing the Cap Space to sign the Player and then operating as a Room Team for the remainder of the Seson.

title: Non-Aggregation
content:
A Team cannot combine multiple Exceptions to acquire a Player over the Salary Cap.

If more than one Exception is available to acquire a Player, then Team can choose which one to use. The choice will depend on (i) preserving the more valuable Exception for future use, or (ii) avoiding a hard cap.

title: Proration of Exceptions
content:
### General Rule

Most Exceptions hold full value until January 10th, at which point they begin reducing in value on a prorated daily basis. There are three Exceptions that have different rules:

1. [Minimum Exception](#minimum) ‚Äì Prorates from the start of the Season;
2. [DPE](#dpe) ‚Äì Does not prorate;
3. [TPE](https://cbaguide.com/transactions/trades/tpe/)‚Äòs ‚Äì Do not prorate.

### Trades and Offer Sheets

If a Team is using an Exception to acquire a Player via [Trade](https://cbaguide.com/transactions/trades/) or to sign a Player to an [Offer Sheet](https://cbaguide.com/transactions/signings/rfa/#offersheet), than the full value of the Exception is still available.

Below are the actual, non-fun, terms used in the CBA:

title: Accruing Bird Rights
content:
To accrue Bird Rights, the Player must (i) be a Veteran Player, (ii) who is a Free Agent, (iii) who **_completed_** a Player Contract other than a [10-Day Contract](https://cbaguide.com/contractanatomy/contracttypes/#tenday) (which can include a [Two-Way Contract](https://cbaguide.com/contractanatomy/contracttypes/#twoway)) with their Prior Team.

1. Non-Bird ‚Äì Satisfies elements above but did not play more than 1 Season with Prior Team.
2. Early bird ‚Äì (i) Played some or all of **two** preceding Seasons with Prior Team, (ii) had changed teams by Trade or Waiver Claim during the first **two** Seasons, or (iii) signed with his Prior Team during the first of the **two** Seasons.
3. Full Bird ‚Äì (i) Played some or all of **three** preceding Seasons with Prior Team, (ii) had changed teams by Trade or Waiver Claim during the first **three** Seasons, or (iii) signed with his Prior Team during the first of the **three** Seasons.

title: The ‚ÄúBird Clock‚Äù ‚Äì Completing a Contract
content:
As stated above, the Player must have _completed_ his Contract with the Prior Team, meaning he must not have been waived. 

However, this rule only applies to his _most recent_ Contract. If he was waived during prior Contracts, you count the accrued Season and you do _not_ reset the Bird Clock.

1. [Waived](https://cbaguide.com/transactions/waivers/) during most recent Contract ‚Äì Bird Clock resets;
2. Waived during prior Contract ‚Äì Bird Rights continue to accrue.

**üèÄ** **A Waiver that Doesn‚Äôt Reset the Clock**  
Year 1 ‚Äì Player is signed and waived mid-season (doesn‚Äôt sign with another Team).  
Year 2 ‚Äì Player signs again with Prior Team. Waived mid-season again (doesn‚Äôt sign with another team).  
Year 3 ‚Äì Plays under a G League Contract until February, then signs a Rest-of-Season Contract with his Prior Team, which he completed.  
Result ‚Äì The Team has Full Bird Rights to the Player since he completed his last Contract and played a portion of 3 prior Seasons with the Prior Team.

title: Renouncing Bird Rights
content:
Renouncing Bird Rights doesn‚Äôt automatically reset the Bird Clock. What it does is relinquishes the Team‚Äôs ability to use Bird Rights to resign the Player.

* If the Team still signs the Player using [Room](#room) or a [Minimum](#minimum) Exception then the Bird Clock continues to accrue.

A Team can also ‚Äúrenounce down‚Äù from Early Bird Rights to Non-Bird Rights. This would allow the Team to sign the Player avoiding the 2-Year minimum length of an Early Bird Contract.

title: Trades/Waivers and Bird Rights
content:
If a Player is [Traded ](https://cbaguide.com/transactions/trades/)or [Waived](https://cbaguide.com/transactions/waivers/), then the Bird Rights typically transfer to the Team acquiring the Player, subject to the following exceptions:

1. Waivers ‚Äì To retain Full Bird Rights he must have been claimed in the first of the three seasons counted toward the Bird Rights.
2. Traded ‚Äì Bird Rights reset to Non-Bird Rights if the Contract (i) is not a Two-Way Contract, (ii) is a 1-Year Contract (excluding Option Year), and (iii) the Player would have Full Bird or Early Bird Rights after the completion of the 1 Year.  
   * This is why there is an [Automatic No Trade Clause](https://cbaguide.com/transactions/trades/traderules/#notrade) for such Contract.

content: If a Player is banned by the NBA and subsequently reinstated, the team can exceed the Salary Cap to resign the Player, limited to 5% raises.

content:

Increases/decreases are limited to 5%.

There are specific roster-building limitations accompanied with falling above each threshold. To determine if a Team is above the Apron Thresholds, **Apron Team Salary** is calculated by taking Team Salary and making certain adjustments discussed below.

On February 6, 2025, the Cavs generated an $8.5 million TPE when they traded Georges Niang to the Hawks as part of the De‚ÄôAndre Hunter trade. However, because the Cavs are over the First Apron and the TPE arose during the Regular Season, the TPE cannot be used unless they drop back below the First Apron.

content: If a Transaction is executed after the Regular Season before the new Salary Cap Year, then the Team must be below the applicable Apron Threshold for the current Salary Cap Year and the subsequent Salary Cap Year.

title: Calculating Apron Team Salary for Subsequent Year
The Hard Cap
content:
**Current Season Hard Cap**

If a Team executes a Transaction that has an applicable Apron threshold, then the Team is **hard capped** and cannot exceed that applicable Apron Threshold for the remainder of the Salary Cap Year.

**üèÄ** **The Kings Acquire Schr√∂der via Sign-and-Trade**  
In July 2025, the Kings acquired Dennis Schr√∂der via Sign-and-Trade. Acquiring a Player via Sign-and-Trade is a First Apron limitation. As a result, the Kings are hard capped at the First Apron for the remainder of the 2025-26 Salary Cap Year.

**Subsequent Season Hard Cap**

If the Team executes the Transaction after the Regular Season but before the new Salary Cap Year, then the Team is also hard capped the _subsequent_ Salary Cap Year.

**üèÄ** **Magic Hard Capped from Offseason Trade**  
In June 2025 (prior to the start of the 2025-26 Salary Cap Year), the Magic used the Aggregated TPE to acquire Desmond Bane. The Magic are hard capped at the Second Apron for the 2025-26 Salary Cap Year.

title: Frozen Pick
content:
If a Team is over the Second Apron at the end of the Regular Season, then its 1st Round Pick in the Draft seven years in the future is **Frozen** can‚Äôt be traded (conditionally or unconditionally).

**üí°** **Which Pick is Frozen?**  
Take the year the Regular Season ended and add seven. This is the year the Draft Pick is frozen. So if the Team is over the Second Apron in the 2027-28 Season. The Regular Season ends in 2028\. 2028 + 7 = 2035 Draft Pick is frozen.

**üèÄ** **Celtics, Suns and Wolves get their Picks Frozen**  
In the first season the Frozen Pick Rule was implemented, the Celtics, Suns and Wolves finished the Regular Season over the Second Apron and saw their 2032 1st Round Picks frozen. We have not had enough time go by to see if the Teams will dip below the Second Apron to avoid the Sliding of those picks (discussed below), or whether those picks will unfreeeze in the future.

title: Sliding or Unfreezing Pick
content:
After the Draft Pick is frozen, you review the subsequent 4 Seasons to determine if it slides to the end of the draft or unfreezes:

1. If the Team exceeds the Second Apron Threshold in 2 of the 4 subsequent Salary Cap Years, then the Frozen Pick slides to the end of the First Round;
2. If the Team exceeds the Second Apron for fewer than 2 of the 4 subsequent Salary Cap Years, the pick will **Unfreeze** after the last day of the Regular Season in the 3rd Year the Team did not exceed the Second Apron.

If multiple Draft Picks in the same Season slide to the end of the Draft, then they are ordered in line with the Team‚Äôs record.

**üí°** **A Pick Will Never Slide and be Unfrozen**  
A pick will _either_ slide to the end of the Draft or unfreeze. There is no circumstance where a pick will slide to the end of the Draft but be unfrozen.

Tax

**The Luxury Tax** is a form of cash penalty used to discourage spending. It has no roster building limitations attached. The amount of cash penalties depend on the Team‚Äôs **Tax Salary** and if the Team is considered a ‚ÄúRepeater‚Äù under the rules.

### Luxury Tax

title: Date of Calculation
content: Tax Salary is determined as of the start of the Team‚Äôs last Regular Season game, subject to a couple of minor adjustments made after the Regular Season.

title: Included in Tax Salary
Excluded in Tax Salary
content:
Exclude the following from Tax Salary:

1. [Likely Bonuses](https://cbaguide.com/contractanatomy/terms/compensation/incentivecompensation/#performance) that were not earned;
2. 50% of [Compensation](https://cbaguide.com/contractanatomy/terms/compensation/) for a League‚Äôs [suspension](https://cbaguide.com/governance/conduct/) of a Player (_not_ a Team suspension).

**‚úçÔ∏è** **50% Reduction Different Between Tax Salary and Total Salaries**  
In Total Salaries, you exclude 50% of the amount reduced in Compensation as a result of suspension by the League _or the Team._ Tax Salary only excludes the reduction for a suspension by the League.

**üèÄ** **Portis Suspension Results in Tax Reduction**  
In 2024-25, Bobby Portis was suspended 25 games for violation of the anti-drug policy. Portis‚Äôs Salary that Season was $12,578,296\. His suspension cost him $2.85 million (1/110 of his Salary multiplied by 25). The Bucks Tax Salary was reduced by 50% of this amount: $1,429,351.
